review_text: Anyone who gives this film higher than a 9 lacks integrity, or just has never seen a good movie: A lot of the late dictator's loyalists will hype this film up but its really, really boring. It's not the worst film I've seen but just like most of Darryl Yap's films, it's trash. Much of the acting from Christine Reyes is just her shouting. It's a grating noise to the ears. The maids in the film are the best part of it as the delivery of their lines are somewhat entertaining, however the lines and "hugots" feel so forced and shallow. The main problem is really the script. The emotional scenes feel so forced. It's obviously a propaganda film and a really boring one at that. It had an okay start but dragged so much at the middle almost as if they were trying to fit a bunch of propaganda from a checklist. The soundtrack and cinematography are okay but not enough to salvage the film. Skip it.

PUTANGINA: I don't know why people review this movie with 1 star, The movie have good combination of comedy and drama, But I think need more cinematography.

Overall the movie is good to watch and not boring but need more improvement.

It's okay.: Entertaining but confusing. Chapters are not connected with each other. It felt like broken and scattered. It felt like something made by an amateur. Great idea, poor execution, great acting tho!

Ferdinand E Marcos Sr is a great president: This movie shows a president who loves his people. I don't call him a dictator. I call him a great president. The Marcos family became victim of many false accuses.. I'm happy they are back.

Another Darryl Yap trademark: Political messages aside, the movie editing is messy and incoherent at times. The scene transitions were bad even for a typical Filipino drama. The acting seems forced and the story direction tries too hard but fails to convince viewers to sympathize with the cast because of badly placed comedic banters in between scenes and badly-written script. It seems like the director didn't learn or even try to improve on his filmmaking formula which has already been frowned upon in his previous films.

Not even worth it: Honestly, I was expecting a coherent turn of events in this film. However, the lack of cinematography bores me to the point it feels like I'm watching a poorly executed youtube skit. As to the transition of the scenes, it was choppy. At first, I thought I'll get used to it but it turns out to be very unnecessary and annoying. The color grading was ok but I supposed they could have done more in terms of the lighting.

Furthermore, the acting was so bland and god it was horrible, in fact one of the actress could not shed a tear in the climax of the film. Nonetheless, the girl with the short hair expresses well with her eyes but her voice screeches sometimes. The dialogues written was plain and bland unfortunately did not engaged us viewers. I was hoping they would take us back to that time but that was not the experience at all.

Overall, the movie felt so rush and unproduced. Not even worth your time.

NO TO HISTORY REVISIONISM/DISINFORMATION: NO TO HISTORY REVISIONISM/DISINFORMATION NO TO HISTORY REVISIONISM/DISINFORMATION NO TO HISTORY REVISIONISM/DISINFORMATION NO TO HISTORY REVISIONISM/DISINFORMATION NO TO HISTORY REVISIONISM/DISINFORMATION NO TO HISTORY REVISIONISM/DISINFORMATION NO TO HISTORY REVISIONISM/DISINFORMATION NO TO HISTORY REVISIONISM/DISINFORMATION NO TO HISTORY REVISIONISM/DISINFORMATION NO TO HISTORY REVISIONISM/DISINFORMATION NO TO HISTORY REVISIONISM/DISINFORMATION.

A Work of Art. Definitely a Masterpiece.: A Family oriented film. The point of view of the Marcos family of the last 72 hours of their stay in Malacañang Palace. Where Cory Aquino wife of a Terorrist/Traitor/Senator Benigno Aquino have robbed the power of the People elected President Ferdinand Marcos Sr. Which is by far the most great,well-loved by the filipino people President, Philippines ever had.

Maid in Malacanang is a sham!: I had an open mind watching this movie. I wanted to give the Marcoses a chance, but I was so wrong. This movie is was not trying to tell the story from the other side. It was a way to manipulate the public, to make the Marcoses look like they were the victims, what a joke! They're trying to cover up the atrocity that the Marcoses did. Stop trying to change the history, it's never gonna work. It's been proven time and time again that truth always win.

Non-bitter movie: To those who gave a negative review to this movie, the question is did everyone watch it? Or do you just want to boycott the movie because there is nothing you can do with the strong support of the people in MIM? Well, for those who are anti Marcos, there is nothing new in your dirty works. I can only say that the plot of the story is very good. You will cry, but you will also laugh at other scenes. You're just really bitter.

Complete waste of time: Cringy acting. Terrible writing. The score is off-putting. The story is obviously self serving. Not for people who are after a real movie. Its like Vlogging with a punctuation.
SO IMPRESSIVE: I love the movie! It shows about what happened in the last days of Marcoses in Palace. I've learned a lot. Thank you for creating this awesome political movie!

It made me cry: Please ignore harsh and negative comments about this movie. Most of them only watched the trailer and never bothered to watch the whole film. They are primarily from people who hate the Marcos family.

I just watched it last night, and it made me cry. I never expected myself to cry over a biopic, semi-documentary film that depicts the last 72 hours of the family of the leader who has been tagged as a dictator in Philippine history.

I don't have much expectation when it comes to local Filipino films. I never bother watching one in the past. But, for this one, I made an exemption.

I have watched maybe a thousand movies and foreign tv series; thus, I have a very high standard when rating one.

For this film, I rate it 6.5 stars.

It's a low-budget movie with a very compelling storyline and dialogue, and I don't want it to end. When it ended, I felt like there were more stories to tell, thus the reason I gave it a 6.5-star rating.

Another reason for my rating is that a few scenes are OA. I hope the director can improve his craft in the sequel movie, MoM - Martyr or Murderer? I am very interested to know what the Marcos family's take about the assassination of Benigno Aquino.

It could've been better.: I know criticism is your enemy, but let's be honest in here.

Apparently, this could've been a good movie if all of these plots and stories were made with true and validated proofs. I could say it's not "bad" to tell the story of the Marcoses-if only they were truthful to what the Marcoses did back-in their last 72-hours in Malacañang. I could say that most of the plot in this movie is just as distorted as ever, although I wanted to hear a single thing that Marcos Sr. Admits his mistakes that he have done to his country back then, but it turns out that this movie came out to be such an anti-climatic, and distorted. I know this is hard to accept, but mocking the Carmelite Sisters playing Mah-Jhong, making Cory falsely say "Let them out of the Philippines" isn't really the most accurate stuff I've ever seen in the movie. There are still missing pieces that I wanted to hear from this movie's script and plot.

I could re-watch it again to re-validate the topics above, but no, Daryl Yap, you should've grabbed the history books and read them well-even if it contains your enemies' stories, learn to accept them-accept the truth for everyone to accept your movie, and not keeping up with those beautiful lies to distort the lads.

I TRIED: Watched this on the first day of release and was in utter disappointment on how bad the whole film was. Setting the fact that the goal of this film was to distort history, the overall production of the film was bad and mediocre. Some actors stood out with their good performances but clearly wasn't enough to save the whole film. Dialogues are weak and bland. There are no remarkable scenes and yes it's safe to say that I wasted my time watching this but hey...I tried.
Stereotype movie: Not worth watching, acting was poor, cinematics are too bland. For a movie that is overly hyped, this movie looks really cheap. I've watched better indie films than this.

The title says it all: a version of a tale of one of the most contentious times in modern Philippine history...: The title says it all: a version of a tale of one of the most contentious times in modern Philippine history as told from the point of view of three domestic helpers employed in the dictator: Ferdinand Marcos Senior's Presidential Palace.

(This is obviously the root of a recent trending topic on Philippine social media pitting historical accuracy against rumor-mongering - with the clear intent to validate this film's point of view.)

With the involvement in this film's production of a lone, single, individual with the last name 'Marcos,' from the entirety of this point in Philippine history; the film is the embodiment of a lone, single, individual's point of view.

Full transparency: this reviewer could only stand the first 30 minutes of the film before storming out because almost all of the events are conveyed through the incessant shouted narration, screamed narration, and complained narration of three fictional maids.

Context was totally absent - leaving the viewer to figure out for themselves and navigate the precise point in history that is being portrayed on film. As a witness to this history, even I could not make heads or tails of it.

Adding to the confusion, the actors playing their respective roles did not even exert any effort to try to emulate the mannerisms, speech patterns, and idiosyncrasies of the historical characters they are portraying. It's a guessing game, distracting from whatever message the film tries to convey, unless the entire nature of this film's existence is to distract.

The constant cutting between re-enactments and historical footage adds to the confusion since no attempt was made to recreate the footage using the actors in the same context. Go figure!

This is bad. Really bad. Really, really bad. If you're a masochist wishing and willing to undergo being constantly screamed at by the help, then, by all means, waste your hard-earned money.

Darryl Yap is a genius!: After 30+ years, Filipinos were able to hear and understand the other side of the story. Kudos to all cast from Apo Lakay to all helpers in the palace! They're all amazing! I underestimated Ella Cruz but she's a really good actress! I wish the movie had more scenes with Irene Marcos. I also love Christine Reyes! More Marcos movies soon, Direk!
Boring and Awkward Acting: Nothing lesson to be learned here. The setting was not really from true as they say in the premiere of the movie. I think this is a historical revisionism as they say.

This movie is for strong-hearted!: Not for losers who cant accept their defeat.

This is not for a fainted and full of envy heart.

Those negative reviews are from those losers who want to spread hate. Stop the Hate.

Waste of money, absolute trash movie: The only thing that is good in this movie is the color-grading lol.

The sequence and the plot is horrible, it goes to nowhere. It's like a clip that's just played and compressed to make a so-called "movie". The actors/actresses are a bit trying hard, especially Ruffa and Cesar (Christine is kinda consistent with the role though)

There was no chemistry among the characters. Even a highschool theatre play is better than this. Absolute flop but thanks to the free tix, should have slept at the cinema instead. LOL.

Not perfect but very Good.: 1. This is a movie, NOT A DOCUMENTARY.

2. This is a movie, NOT HISTORY.

3. This is a movie, NOT a biopic.

As a movie is has more values, values about family.

It has some serious moments as well as funny one.

Art is subjective.

You are the one who have a problem if you view this as a HISTORICAL REVISIONISM.

I would've gave this film a zero but since I can't, I GIVE IT A ONE: Two words: history revisionism. This is the worst film ever, not only is it history revisionism, I might as well call it historical fiction. I really dislike this film, I enjoy Filipino documentaries because as a Filipina myself, it sparks nationalism in my heart but this movie? Not only did it do the polar opposite of what films usually make me feel but it made me sick to my stomach. This film is truly the worst, I cannot believe many Filipinos praise it as if it doesn't showcase history revisionism. Do not watch this film unless you are used to listening to lies.

Waste of time: It's just pure trash. Ledt the cinema 15 mins into the movie. Historical distortion. And they really though they did something there, huh? Not sure if the genre is horror or comedy. The movie reeks of desperation and narcism. Save yourself from torture.

Historical Revisionism: If I could give it -1, I would. I wouldn't, for the life of me, recommend this to anyone as the movie is trying to make the viewers sympathize with the oppressors, painting them in a good light when these people weren't, aren't and won't ever be the victims.

WORST FILM IN PHILIPPINE CINEMA!: This film aims to distort history and actual events. A work of pure fiction and fantasy!

The exile of the Marcoses in Hawaii was a result of a peaceful 1986 EDSA Revolution. An end of tyranny and dictatorship.

This film attempts to whitewash viewers to deliberately conceal the mistakes, conceal unpleasant, incriminating FACTS about the Marcoses and their family name.

No to Historical revision and distortion. NEVER FORGET!

Great movie and worth to watch!: I already watch this movie and It was a great movie every scene and lines will touch your heart the actors are also great they potrayed it well and it is also worth it.

History revisionism made into a film: Do not watch, a complete waste of time. Most of the 10 star reviews are mostly from the director's team.

The director even insulted nuns and historians just to market his said film. I don't understand why this film even got out.

Kulang!: Nakulangan Ako sa mga detalye Nung political turn of events in the last 72 hours. Pero it took me by surprise to know that Maids were treated as part of the family.

Very nice movie. Not so cinematic but meaty. I love the last part. People in the cinema really applauded. It was something remarkable and unexpected. People are hungry of more truth on the other side of Philippine History.

10 starts!

Worst Philippine movie of all time: Promotes history distortion, misinformation and lies. Most of the scenes are fiction, bias and not based on facts!!! Not recommended to watch!!! You cannot hide the truth, deaths and sufferings that were experienced by the Filipino people during Martial Law!!! Stop misinformation, history distortion and lies! #NeverAgain.

The Best Filipino Movie: This movie is the best. It doesn't try to impress you. It shows a story of a family who faces challenges just like every family. Kudos to Director, Mr Darryl Yap and all the cast. The acting skills of the actors are superb! I cried and laugh. That scene between President FEM and President BBM hit me big time.

Not recommended...: We were given free movie passes and out of boredom watched this movie. Very few people watched it here in Baguio so there's no hassle waiting in line. The movie has cringey dialogs, shallow story-line, no character development and no entertainment value of any kind. The so called 'untold history' they claim is not convincing at all. Glad I got this movie free or else I would have spent 350 pesos for such a senseless film.

I TRIED TO CHECK THE "OTHER SIDE OF THE COIN": SO I WATCHED THIS SINCE I ALWAYS SEE POST REGARDING THIS FILM, BOTH GOOD AND BAD. I ENDED UP BEING DISSAPOINTED AT THE WORST WAY POSSIBLE BY WATCHING THIS. THIS IS LIKE WATCHING YOUTUBE MOVIES, BUT WORSE. JUST WASTED MONEY AND TIME DAMM*T...

history revisionism: Maid in Malacañang (2022) Directed by: Darryl Yap

Huling tatlong araw ng mga Marcos sa Malacañang... Ano ang nangyari ?

The movie didn't give the experience of a family in their last 72 hours.

The progression of events is anti-climactic.

The flow of conversation is dull.

The choice of words is hollow.

The storytelling is not cohesive.

It feels like you're watching some YouTube skits, TV Patrol excerpts, Theater scenes and SOCO rolled into one.

News. Drama. Documentary.

Fiction. Biopic. Comedy.

Fantasy. Tribute. History.

They didn't know what to tell and how to tell it, so they showed a bit of every other thing.

They just combined all their scenes by inserting "chapters" and "long texts" in between that literally summarizes what they want to tell-which defeats the purpose of a movie.

Some scenes give the impression of one long continuous shot. It actually works when Cristine Reyes is in the scene.

Si Cristine Reyes ang nagdala ng pelikula. Tumataas ang tensyon kapag siya na ang nasa eksena.

Magaling umiyak si Ella Cruz. Masaya ang tambalan nila Karla Estrada, Elizabeth Oropesa at Beverly Salviejo.

Walang dating si Cesar Montano.

Walang emosyon si Diego Loyzaga.

Walang ginawa sina Kiko Estrada at Kyle Velino.

Mas malakas ang prisensya nina Robin Padilla at Giselle Sanchez kahit ilang segundo lang sila nagpakita.

Hindi marunong umarte si Ruffa Gutierrez. Lumuluha na pero mukhang nagpapatawa pa rin.

Mas magaling pa umarte yung bodyguard na taga-Ilocos daw.

Meron mga salita na hindi naman ginagamit nuon. Pero lantaran nilang sinasabi sa pelikulang ito.

The scoring is deceiving, trying to enhance the scene-even when there's nothing remarkable in it.

Then by the end, there's a sudden tribute to characters that were not given its decent exposure during the actual movie runtime. An illusion that something is made for them-when it is not.

Mapanlinlang ang pelikula.

Makalat ang kabuuan.

Pero hinding hindi ka makakatulog.

Gising ka sa lahat ng kaganapan.

Katulong ka sa paghubog ng kasaysayan.

This movie doesn't deserve a single star: Maid in Malacañanb is a pure work of fiction and only promotes historical revisionism. This movie doesn't deserve a single star at all. Complete waste of money.

Good: Well many reviews here actually came from opposition followers, bad attitude who dont even watch the movies but review it poorly.

You are just anti Marcos and you will not accept anything good.

K bye.

NO SENSE AT ALL: This movie is a trash. From the beginning until the end are just insults to the Aquino Family. The storyline is bragging about the Marcos' family and very not true to the facts of history.

The best FOR ALL FILIPINOS.: The best Movie so far. Its for every patriotic FILIPINOS. THIS IS THE TRUTH CONGRATULATIONS DIREK DARRYL VIVA AND SEN IMEE MARCOS

MORE MOVIES PLEASE.

Best Circus Film: Thank you for free tickets governors and senators. I've never seen such a great circus film in Philippine Cinema.

I would also like to commend the paid trolls who made 10 star ratings. You guys are truly hard working. Kudos to the Marcoses too for doing the best job in Robbing their own country men.

Phenomenal!: This is the side that we wanted to see. Thanks to those who gave their roles justice. I also like how it did not paint any colors at all. We need movies that tell the other side of the story.

Worst Movie, Had high expectations.: I had high expectations for this film because of Daryl Yap the director of "Jowable" and "Ang Babaeng Walang Pakiramdam", but this was a catastrophe. It was long, featured corny language, and was largely wrong. The movie focuses less on the real story and more on making the viewers hate "the other side". This movie is just so jam-packed with content that it is a complete mess. Regarding the cinematography and plot, It was decent but still not enough. A Marcos movie had so much promise, yet this was a tremendous waste.

Didn't Live Up: The social media marketing of this movie has lied to me and everyone else. There was no line "It's maiding time" and Gagamba Boy never showed up in the climax. Daryll Yap does not know history he didn't even add the nutribuns that the yellows have stolen from the palace. VERY BIG DISAPPOINMENT, DON'T WATCH WASTE, STORY WAS NOT GOOD 2/10.

NO TO HISTORY DISTORTION: The movie was made in order to gain the sympathy of the people by portraying imaginary events that never really happened. They should instead focus on making plans for Philippine's future and plan how to counter the problems we are currently experiencing instead of spreading false information.

Brilliant Movie with sense of humor!: This side of the story had long been suppressed to be unraveled to the Filipino people since time immemorial. This mysterious side had always been depicted as the darkest and people in control of information, breeds a notion that it's a damnation to have knowledge about this side. In fact, Philippine history books instill very negative pictures about a past President, while numerous living grandparents and ordinary folks who were witnesses of his reign (including my father, uncles and aunts) were all praises and admiration, calling him the "Best Philippine President ever" were undocumented.

This movie stirs additional curiosity to every Filipino as the story revolves from the point-of-view of the first family, being revealed and heard of for the first time.

A very family-oriented and brilliant movie you shouldn't miss!

As we are intelligent beings, it is but normal to be flipping both sides of the coin. It is a man's liberation and a test of humanity to have knowledge in all sides then decide his subjective judgment which side to believe in.

Trash: This a movie meant to distort studied historical accounts and provoke people in a negative way. It's only a movie which is fictitious but unfortunately, many Filipinos don't know how determine which is true or not. The scenes were inaccurate and depicts false events or posture them for the benefit of a political family. (barf)

THE BEST FILIPINO MOVIE OF THE YEAR!: I cried 3 times while watching this movie. The movie is one of kind. It tells the story how human even how powerful a person can be. A story of a whole family and how they cope up on a crisis. A must watch for everybody!

It's a piece of ART!

Kudos to Darryl Yap and to all the Cast!

FANTASY: The movie isn't based on true events. Fantasy stories created by senator Chin (Babalu). The director and his researchers are too silly for not having a thorough research. It is like a movie with no sense.

Highly recommended: The movie is more on family drama. Yaya biday is the star of the movie. The scene of FEM & Young Bongbong almost make my heart tears. And kudos to Ella(Irene Marcos) you really did a great job. And to cristine reyes who played manang Imee. You deserve a best actress award. To Director Darryl Yap "JOB WELL DONE." And more to come.

Trash. Not realistic. Exaggerated. pathetic: This movie contains scenes that did not happen in reality.

Some scenes that were not true to life events:

* The Filipino people who climb in the gate carrying a torch with fire were not true. They were not aggressive and there is a PROOF of images.

* One author of the article recently said that the MIM team misunderstand the context of her article about cory playing mahjong. So basically they lack comprehension.

THE POINT OF MY REVIEW IS THAT THIS MOVIE IS TRASH. IT WASTED MY TIME AND MONEY. There were scenes where they exaggerate to make it look like the dictator's family was also victims.

Would rate this lower than one star if possible: The only saving grace was that the ticket was free.

The writers did a poor job with their research, this much is apparent. Painfully obvious how the narrative tried to bend reality. Hence the cringe script.

Acting was subpar, it felt awkward. The actors were misguided, perhaps in their direction on how to attack such scenes. At some points, scenes felt surreal. Good thing there were some funny tidbits.

Scenes were oftentimes monotonous, yet sometimes overbearing at the same time. The shrill zany acting in the second half of the film is just irritating at best.

This film has painted a negative narrative for President Cory Aquino. According to this film, during the EDSA Revolution in 1986, the late president dared to gamble with nuns whilst the Philippines' democracy is under siege.

On the other hand, the thesis of this film was to depict the Marcoses in a better light. However, the appeal to pity was unsuccessful.
Bad movie: Huhuhu daamn I assume it's a great movie but it doesn't, I guess my money wasted in this one. I shouldn't support this movie before. Now I exclude myself to 31M.

Historical Distortion: This movie isnt even accurate if you want to watch an accurate of what happen try watching kingmakers on YouTube...

Oh btw the acting sucks so i dont even recommend this to anyone

This is one of the most Controversial and Important films in Philippine History.: It is very unique and has its own style for a film. It really gives you a new perspective of the EDSA Revolution and tells the other side of the history of the Philippines in 1986.

It finally showed what was happening inside Malacañang during those times. In the film you could actually connect some parts of it to Philippine history and would make absolute sense.

Also, if you watched the film you would know that it never distorted history instead it filled those gaps in history. Director Darryl Yap, who is also the screenwriter of the film, did an excellent job with this film that it really made Philippine Cinema returned.

A movie based on lies and fake information: You could watch the movie but it would be a waste of your time since the story was based on a narrative without factual basis. This movie should not have been shown at the very 1st place since it distorts written actual history of the Philippines. I was actually wanting to see what really happened back there however the movie failed to show proof of it.

Not a history distortion and hard truth: Actors and actresses were fit for the roles.

This is not a history distortion movie. In fact, the old footages are in the film from various media.

It's a story of the last 72 hours of Marcoses in the Palace which was hidden for a long time.

Poor. Hastily done. Too amateurish.: It seems this was done in just a few days. Screenplay and direction is not at par. If anything, this movie should pay us - as we wasted time, that we can't get back.

Casting wasn't well thought of. It also seems actors were selected based on who were willing to join a bandwagon. Diego Loyzaga, Ella Cruz and Ruffa Gutierrez should be ashamed to be in this industry.

Superb!: I cried and laugh many times in this movie. You can relate what character feels. Each of us has it's own story to tell and no one can invalidate that.

We are tired of hearing the other story for 4 decades.

I can't find any revisionism in this movie.

Congrats Daryll Yap and all the cast!

Poor story telling. Lame script. Doesn't really show the last 72 hours in Malacañang.: Overall, it's a lame movie. The only regret I have is wasting my time watching this so called "movie". There's no art in this. By far the worst movie I've even watched.

historical distortion: Please do not watch this film. It will be a total waste of your time. Too much historic disinformation in an attempt to brainwash the audiences and filipino citizens in favor of the current Marcos adminisration. What a cheap act.

Historical FICTION, Distortion and Insult: Historical FICTION, Distortion and Insult No to history distortion!!!!!

The Production of Maid in Malacañang was a big disrespect to the Martial Law Victims and to our historians.

False Informations: This movie is a hearsay. Some scenes are pure fiction and is denied by the written history. The movie is an attempt to distort history and the painful past that the Filipino people has gone through the Marcoses.

NO HISTORICAL REVISIONISM: I attended a special screening organized by the 31 Million Movement from Facebook last August 5th held at Greenbelt 3 in Makati. Even it's too far from my house, I rode an Angkas taxi even with torrential rain since I was so late and got all wet, because I know that it will be all worth it. And it did. No disappointments nor any dissatisfaction. I even met Billy Jake Cortez and Julinana Parizcova Segovia, special guests for this screening.

The movie itself was good. The actors who portrayed every character has their own distinction, and were of high caliber. No historical revisionism was made nor inteded on this movie as the others were telling. They just told the untold stories of the Marcoses during their last 72 hours in The Malacañan Palace.

Congratulations to Direk Darryl Yap for yet another masterpiece and can't wait for the rest of the Trilogy to be released.

PANGIT: Don't waste your time watching this movie. JUST DON'T. This has so much bs. Couldn't even fathom how the PDF Director stomached this. Such thick skinned animal should not be a Director in the first place. Anyways, f the marcoses. You still cannot erase the atrocities happened in the oh-so-great golden era.

MUST WATCH : One of the best Filipino movies of all time. Directing and acting was superb! You will cry and laugh ! It was a story of family and love of country. Can't get enough of it! No wonder it's a blockbuster hit! A MUST WATCH!

Thrash: Looks like a school project converted into a movie, funded by the Marcos. A movie that based on lies and historical distortion. There is nothing interesting on its story. It's great mockery to the Philippine history.

Don't mind the 1star reviews: First of all, don't even waste your time reading all the 1-star reviews that were given to this movie. They are just mad because they are driven by the fear that their narratives might be overshadowed.

Second of all, this is just a FAMILY drama and intended to show their side of the story that other people outside the President's residence are not aware of.

Plot: This is just a straightforward dramedy that tells the struggles of the first family of the Philippines during their last 72 hours inside the Malacañang palace. The movie is divided by chapters. Of course it touched politics, but more than that it was a Family drama. The story was told with a mix of truth and artistic view. The movie will make you cry and laugh at the same time.

Tone: It was made to entertain and educate as well. It highlights what is obvious in Politics; trust, betrayal, loyalty, etc. Most importantly, it really tackles the importance of family during difficult times.

Acting and Characters: All the actors have played their roles really well. It seems that each character's attitude and behavior fit the actor who played it. Every scene is remarkable and will pinch your heart as if you are part of the scene. You can feel the emotions in every dialogue exchange, as if they are not acting and just comes out naturally.

Cinematography: There were scenes where the camera is panning in circular motion as if the movie is showing the audience how this family's life is turning upside down especially the scene between the mother and her son. The movement and acting are aligned and the actors are properly framed.

Summary: This may be my own opinion about the movie, but I can assure you that this is a legit review as I have already watched the entire film. Don't rely on the reviews having 5 stars and below, there are some Anti Marcos out there that don't even bother to watch the whole movie yet they are leaving reviews as if they are being good critics when in fact they are just bitter because another Marcos has returned in Malacañang.
Historical distortion: Trash. Based on chismis. Based on an apologists' point of view. Poorly constructed. Lame excuse for a comedy movie. Wouldn't recommend this even on pirated download.

Lack of taste, poorly made and boring: It does not have any exciting parts honestly. I was waiting for it the whole time while watching it. Very disappointing and a total waste of money. Also, no to historical distortion. This movie is so far from the truth. That is the number one thing viewers should put in mind. This movie has no finesse. Trashy in most sense. Thats the perfect word for this movie.

Not worth your money and time: Movie is too biased. Better watch documentaries to know the truth.

Movie is too biased. Better watch documentaries to know the truth.

Movie is too biased. Better watch documentaries to know the truth.

Movie is too biased. Better watch documentaries to know the truth.

history distortion: This movies is pure lies.

It's all about misinformation, revisions of history.

The intent is surely to mislead the people far from the truth and create a fictional narrative to what happened on the last 72hrs before the marcoses left the Philippines.

i can watch it over and over again: It took a lot of effort and courage to get right esp. For marcoses I think the actors captured the characters well. I definitely believed they were someone else while they were in that movie. I've never been this impressed with someone else's performance before. Maid in malacanang is amazing sentimental movie. Title doesn't fit with the supposed narrative: I expected to see what was just happening with the family 72 hours before they got exiled. Like a documentary of sorts, what they did, how much they were forced to leave behind

"Huling tatlong araw ng mga Marcos sa Malacañang, ano ang nangyari?" was the supposed plot

Yet, the movie didn't give the experience of a family in their last 72 hours

The progression of events is anti-climactic

The flow of conversation is hollow

The choice of words contribute to the hollowness

The storytelling is disorderly

Continuously changes format narratives

I think if they stuck to a "documentary" type of movie it would've fit well

They didn't know what to tell and how to tell it, so it became an amalgamation of every movie format possible

They just combined all their scenes by inserting "chapters" and "long texts" in between that literally summarizes what they want to tell-which defeats the purpose of a movie

Cristine Reyes carried the movie, Ella Cruz has solid crying acts

Cesar Montano, playing the infamous dictator, has no semblance of the supposed 'strongman' traits of the one he's playing Diego Loyzaga literally has no emotion

Others didn't do anything Looking at you Kiko Estrada

Misrepresentation of nuns with Giselle Sanchez playing mahjong already crosses this film out as a supposed "addition" to history, since said nuns are cloistered

Usage of words that were not present those days, but are yet frequently heard in the movie

Usage of musical scores are way off, since most of the scores play in scenes that are unremarkable

Then by the end, there's a weird and sudden tribute to characters that were not given its decent exposure during the actual movie runtime. An illusion that something is made for them - yet the movie is portraying a supposed tribute for the said dynasty

In the end, you'd stay awake because it isn't boring, but you're trying to understand why the movie is made as it is, and the supposed plot and the actual output strayed so far

An obvious but weak attempt at REVISING Philippine history: Maid in Malacañang is a recent film touted as the story told by an unknown and unverified source (the "maid") of the last 72 hours of the Marcos' family inside Malacañang Palace, the official residence of the Philippine president and his family. What makes the movie historically false is that there are scenes featuring Corazon Aquino, then the main opposition presidential candidate. How was the source or the "maid" able to tell what was happening to Mrs. Aquino when she was about 900 kilometers away at that time? When a movie shows historical falsehood it can only be considered as a fantasy/fictional movie and should never be taken seriously. If you want to waste time, money, and effort, then do watch this film.

Majority if not all Negative reviews here are from the losing party last election with the line " let me educate you".: Movie is good... It gives us a chance to see the other side of the coin in a widely monopolized story in the history of Philippines and it's politics... Its a window to peep in inside the seat of power in the country using the eyes of those people who were actually there to see it and not from the lens of others who have tried to suppress the flipping of the coin.

You will appreciate the storyline, the portrayals and all if you go and watch with neutral stance on matters concerning Philippine politics..but of course, not easy to do for a person like , being an ilocano descent with over 20 years of exposure to the monopolized truth taught in schools from elementary to college pair it with a conflicting view and accounts from elders who have actually lived throughout the heavily pixelized Marcos and Aquino Eras.. Again, the reason why we paid individual tickets to o enter the movie house is because we watch every movie as it is and perceive it individually, so , it is for us to judge and discern and not let others grow and sow their own personal biases inside of us... Going back to the movie Itself, in all fairness, It did not imply to discredit what the other story line has been depicting all these years, it was just there to tell its own story....so I don't know where the hate is coming from , maybe, they'll just afraid to see that there is really another angle equally important to look at and consider aside from their get go and comfortable, well written, published and universally true side... Bottom line is, when it tingles a little bit in your spine and you somehow have the means to watch it, go... And tell yourself what you think... Don't let them be the judge for you...enjoy the movie , and if in some way you have spare, then go watch the other movie too...

1 star rates are fake and they did not watch the movie at all, yellowtard please move on from the last election.: The MIM is not a documentary movie. It is neither a historical biopic nor a political film.

It is not about martial law. It is the untold story about Edsa Uno.

It is a drama movie... a story of an aspect of the fall of the powerful Filipino family. The fall of the Marcoses did not just happen in Edsa Uno; it started when President Marcos decided to stay in power for life and culminated in February 25, 1986.

It is not intended to alter the dominant Edsa People Power narrative. But it provides us a glimpse of what happened in the other side of Edsa, the Malacanang Palace.

It is not historical revisionism as alleged by the sanctimonious among us who appointed themselves as protectors of our history.

After watching the movie, I wonder why the yellows (rebranded as Pinks; a masked people or balatkayo) and the anti-Marcos people are making much political noise about the movie.

It is a story about what happened to the Marcos during the last days in power.

A film about a powerful political family facing the reality of their collapse.: The film portrayed the last three days leading to the fall of the Marcos family and their exile to Hawaii in 1986.

Taking away the political bias, the context of the film was about how each family member responded and acted to the realization that their world, their paradigm, was about to shatter because of betrayal which is a universal theme that everyone can relate to.

The cinematography was good, limited by the fact that the film had a meager budget and there was only one or two shooting locations for the movie. The soundtrack was well-thought of and laid out very well throughout the movie. Editing was better than most Filipino films that I personally had seen.

The acting was top-notch, and this is coming from a non-viewer of Filipino films---the performances were riveting and heart-wrenching which took me by surprise and disarmed me which is probably because so many people had given the movie bad reviews based on the trailer and not actually watching it. There were scenes which were jarring to paranoia tempered by scenes that were light-hearted and cringingly humorous. My only wish was that the costumes, props, and settings were more historically accurate, but I will cut it some slack since there wasn't much of a budget to begin with.

I would gladly recommend this movie to everybody, and would like to encourage everyone to have an open mind and the suspension of disbelief when going in the movie theatre. One's politics is only a small fraction of one's personality, so leave it at the doorstep and enjoy a rollercoaster ride.

The very existence of this film and its supporters spit on the lives and suffering of those who were unfortunate enough to dwell under thetyranny of the Marcoses' rule.

History Revised!: This is purely fictional. The Producer is Imee Marcos so expect that the movie will revolve around her. It portrays the lavish lifestyle that the Marcos' had but them being so nationalistic and very concerned with the Filipino people was distorted in the movie. The funny thing is that the Marcos' relied on the gossips of the maids for their decision making. That in itself was already a red flag. The actual footages of the videos from the EDSA Revolution were just spliced to fit in the fictional storyline. The movie would appeal to the blind masses that are loyalists to the Marcos'. The whole events that happened in the palace were romanticized by the director like the Bongbong and Imelda drama in the bed, the father and son talk of Sr and Jr, Marcos and his daughter Irene, the speech of the 3 maids and the households,etc to make the movie palatable. As a fictional movie, it was OK but as representative of history, have more discernment when watching this.

The story, indeed, runs contrary to what historical records show. There was an attempt to make the film appear to be a documentary but the lack of empirical evidence/proof as basis made it lackluster. The lousy editing made it even worse. It is like watching short videos woven together. It is not cohesive. And remarkable only for being utterly disappointing.

The musical scoring is weird. The music is ok but feel displaced as some unimportant scenes were heavily scored while the others were left disserviced by a musical scoring.

The direction of Mr Yap is also lackluster. The costumes and makeup were acceptable, but not noteworthy.

Overall, I think it will be better if they just showed it for free in youtube or other platforms for it is not worth paying good money for in cinemas. If, as the critics say, it is a tool for propaganda, then make it free for viewing. Leave the cinemas for actual movies worth they money we pay for it.

The film was boring and full of crap. Entirely a lie from start to finish.: Free movie stubs were given to us by some friends therefore, although I hated the thought of watching the movie, I came in to watch it with a friend. We were stuck watching the film just so we can sit on something.

First of all, don't believe these people giving this piece of crap positive reviews, these are people the director himself asked to review the movie and rate it with the highest score. The truth is, this movie was made to distort Philippine Marcos regime history. The movie clearly depicted an unlikable Cory Aquino ( Marcos' rival to the Presidential post ) to feed people with a false belief that Cory was the " antagonist" and the Marcoses we're victims of treachery and oppression of the Filipino people. The truth is, the director of this film is a friend to the Marcoses and he was paid to create a fictional version of the Marcoses story of the last 72 hours of them in Malacanang before they flee to the U. S. by force, as the Philippines had enough of their atrocities, corrupt administration and the poverty they left the country with due to their incapacity to lead the country to progress. The people had enough of them and they were attacked by the people after 2 decades under Martial Law.

The movie showed a Cory Aquino playing mahjong with some nuns while the Philippines was at war with the Marcoses. I mean, Would anyone ever think of playing mahjong while their lives are in danger and their country's state is uncertain? I don't think anybody will have the nerve to even sleep peacefully at a certain point, all the more, these people depicted to be playing mahjong are nuns and the late President Cory. This movie even managed to disrespect the nuns who brought Cory Aquino to hide with them while the Marcoses were hunting her. The movie made them seem as if they were uncaring at the time of crisis. The scene was senseless, blasphemous and laughable, as if the director tries so hard to degrade the nuns and ruin the name if the late President on purpose.

It also showed the Filipinos during the late 80's in the most advance city in the Philippines, mind you, holding torches while attacking the Malacanang Palace. What kind of activists in their sound mind would rally to the Presidential palace and while holding torches and in the late years of 1980's? Really torches in the 1980's? And people from the city in that time, holding them torches? What a funny fart ignorance of a movie this is. I don't know whether to laugh at the scene or just leave lol.

Had I known it was this ridiculous, I would have given my ticket to someone else. The movie was very inaccurate, provocative and utterly a dismay, a laughable senseless depiction, or fictionalization of characters, events and the entire history at the Marcos regime. A waste of our time.

Funny that 1 star-reviews are from those who didn't actually watch the film. Pathetic!: I was disappointed. I was disappointed that there was no "historical revisionism" in the movie, just like what is exploding now in social media saying the film is trying to revise history. The film only revolves around the story of the Marcos family, the people, and what is happening inside the Malacañang during the 1986 People Power Revolution. The actors were great! Christine Reyes was so damn awesome actress! Surely, the movie proved that Imee is a badass. Hahaha I was surprised that Ella Cruz's acting was great, too! The dramatic scenes can be heavy, so I suggest you bring tissue or hanky. I was preventing myself to wipe my tears at first, but when I saw other people sobbing unashamedly, I didn't stop myself. LOL I love that Director Darryl Yap added some comedy scenes to the film as a breather for the heavy drama. I enjoyed the film and I think it was also appreciated by the people who watched it, because the cinema in SM Aura where we were in exploded in applause after the film ended. I even heard people say, "Ang galing!" "Shocks, ang ganda." while clapping their hands. Awesome movie! Watch it, and leave a review only after you did so. ;)

This movie is not an attempt to revise history of the philippines but an attempt suply stories that has been deprived to be heard more than 3 decades ago. It is good to know the the totality of the history before drawing a particular judgment. It is illogical to directly discredit a particular experience of history just because such experience is not popular or not in congruent to what has been accepted. History is not an exclusive per se but an all-inclusive collection of recollected events in the past which undergoes series of scrutiny and validation in consideration of its truthful product. If you are not a Filipino be informed first before drawing your conclusion. Do not be fed with bias media instead go to the Philippines and make your further research. It sounds plausible when you listen to both sides of the story before you make any judgment about Martial Law or the Marcoses.

A Movie Worth Watching: Kudos to the writer and director, Daryl Yap, for crafting a historical movie with fairness and facts. It's about time that the Marcos family be heard after 36 years.

Congratulations also to the actors for portraying their roles excellently!

SINO BA SILA?: It is not my habit to watch films on the first day they're shown in theaters. Knowing "Maid in Malacañang" is viral, popular, and controversial, I knew the cinemas would be packed so I did not make it an exception.

I watched it on the second day yet the theater was still full.

This movie is about a family that Filipinos are used to see on TV and read in newspapers and magazines, but never seen and heard behind closed doors.

This is the first time to see the candid side of the Marcoses and how they dealt with one of the most tumultuous parts of their regime.

The first part had the "Nosi Balasi" playing in the background, which made me think of the critics and the detractors that continue to discredit the Marcoses and their supporters through the years.

When you read the lyrics of this song, you'll realize that's exactly how the Marcoses treated their critics in the last 36 years.

I knew this film only presents one of the many perspectives of the so-called People Power Revolution in 1986. As the movie progressed, however, it became evident that two main perspectives are being narrated: those of the "maids" or the kasambahays, and that of the other "maid" in Malacanang who promised her father to tell their story in due time: Imee Marcos.

Others may disagree with me on this but I see this film more as Imee's perspective of events as the "panganay" and as the unpaid "maid" in Malacanang, who did her best to give order to chaos and make some of the important decisions for her family during the last 72 hours of her father's regime.

Having watched so many of Imee's vlogs and interviews, I can only imagine what she was like behind closed doors. It was Christine Reyes' portrayal of the character that gives glimpses of Imee's younger self in a way that I believed she was Imee. Christine showed Imee's facets convincingly: she was feisty, a quick thinker, always on her toes, decisive, a multi-tasker, and at times appeared to be a control freak.

The stories of the helpers inside the palace gave me a roller coaster of emotions; but more importantly, they gave the audience an idea of how the Marcoses treated their workers. The fact that the maids could be candid around the president, the first lady, and their children speaks volumes.

They also had accounts that painted the Marcoses as "just like other good employers".

One important bit that got me was when the maids showed their furs given by Imelda. The former First Lady told them that they, too, deserved to own furs. This reminded me of what FEM and Imelda often talk about in their writings and interviews: to give dignity to the Filipino people.

Of course, I couldn't help but mentally "fact-check" and compare some information in the movie with what I read from books and other publications throughout the campaign period.

The part about mainstream media spreading fake news that the Marcoses had already left Malacanang when they were still in the palace can be found in Paul Goldstein's article in EIR Journal dated July 25, 1986.

There was also the bit about Cory winning the elections based on NAMFREL's tally and FEM winning based on COMELEC's tally. You can find this info in Cecilio Arillo's book, A Country Imperiled and Rigoberto Tiglao's book, Debunked.

The part where the people at EDSA headed to Radio Veritas can be found in Paul Goldstein's article in EIR dated July 15, 1986

There's also something I noticed that's unique in this film that I don't see often in other Filipino films: the art of long takes.

A "long take" is a shot that's intended to appear as a single, uninterrupted take in the final edit of a film.

I thought this was interesting as it made the scenes appear more intimate. Long takes can draw you closer to the scene. At times, I felt transported into the story as if I were there in the moment with the characters, but as a silent and invisible observer.

As the camera gracefully glided from one angle to another, the drama and tension became more palpable. That's because long takes mimic the real-life scenarios of freely moving through space and time while expressing feelings of agony, confusion, and fear.

I jokingly posted yesterday on Facebook: "Who wrote the screenplay, Direk? Because it was attempting to make me cry."

And I did cry an ugly cry. Darryl, you're a brilliant writer. I felt the suffering, the confusion, the hopelessness, and the shattering of the souls of the characters.

The simplest of lines can turn those who are hardened into misty-eyed. You will identify something very personal in your own life with a line, a scene, a character, or a moment in this movie. I am not sure anyone could have written the screenplay any better as you did.

Another thing that I liked about this film is there were almost no actions and no special effects -- just a family and their staff talking to one another sometimes in a group, sometimes just between two people or among the family members. It's the simplicity of it that highlights its sentimental edge with dialogues so movingly performed.

You'll probably never find the stories of these characters in any publications mainly because they chose to remain quiet for decades or maybe they were not given the chance to air their side.

While others will most likely question the accuracy of the narratives in this film, no one should invalidate them especially when these perspectives come from characters who LIVED inside Malacanang for several years.

Like I said several times in my previous posts, there are hundreds or even thousands of ways to narrate an event depending on who is telling it.

Maid in Malacañang is about the perspectives of those inside the palace at the time when the opposition and the people on EDSA also crafted their own stories to tell.

All perspectives are valid, especially of those who were in the same rooms as the president of the Republic These perspectives are pieces that help complete a puzzle that perplexed the nation for decades.

The movie did not negate exiting perspectives at all. In fact, perspectives should be looked at and treated separately without prejudice against one another. This is how we understand both sides objectively. This is how we form a more complete picture of an important event in our history.

Maid in Malacañang is about how it makes you feel in the end. This movie makes me feel hopeful as a Filipino because, perhaps, this can help pave the way to national reconciliation so we can finally move on together as one.

GREAT MOVIE, IT'S HIGH FOR THE MARCOS'S SIDE: From CockyRocky (Facebook page Cocky Rocky, please follow him for all insights)

After military and rebel forces in collusion with the USA and the Catholic Church in the Philippines stole the 1986 snap elections from the democratically elected president, the late Ferdinand E. Marcos, rioters, looters and criminals stormed Malacañang Palace. Darkness swept across the land as a Yellow dictator illegally took over the government.

This was the start of the decline of our country's fortunes. Infrastructure, culture and the arts, agriculture, technology and even education gradually deteriorated due to her government's incompetence and corruption. The departure of the Marcoses signaled the start of our national trials and tribulation.

But. History is not through with the Marcoses.

The story of our country's success, security and prosperity begins again. Two great families - powerhouses, polar opposites and legacies - have come, a son of the North and a daughter of the South. Together, they are electrifying the world with their statecraft.

What a glorious time to be alive, to be a Filipino. Philippine history is upended. The truth and lies which were deviously but masterfully mangled, marbled and warped through the passage of time are now under scrutiny. This is a reckoning. We are fighting not just for our stories today but for everyday that we have lost since the historical revision which began in 1986.

The past - hidden by the hate-filled lies of the academics, the clergy and the media - are finally seeing the Philippine sunrise for the first time. Let it not be dimmed and cowed into obscurity again.

An Actual Objective Review of the Movie: Okay. I am writing this because I just watched it earlier.

First of all, folks, the movie is not "bad". You only deem it bad because it portrays the side of the Marcoses.

Second, Have you watched it? Have you actually bought tickets to see the film? If yes, did you watch it for entertainment? Or did you watch it as your source for "the truth". Because if you went for the latter, then you're a snowflake and you just proved the other party's point that they can trigger you. Your source of information shouldn't be on what you see on the movies. It's a movie, give everyone a break.

Third, they portrayed the side of the Marcoses. If you think your idea of their own experiences should be followed, then you go make and produce the movie.

Fourth, when did you actually see a Marcos film post 1986? You know, the one that depicts their part of the story, even if it was bad. Was there? Honest question. Because I don't think there ever was. And this was the perfect film for it. Admit it or not, post 1986 we were already bombarded with Anti-Marcos, Pro Aquino, NPA, Martial Law events and victims movies - BUT. NOT. ONE. MARCOS. FILM.

Anyway, here is my take on the movie.

First five-ish "Chapters" of the movie went on with no cut scenes. I found this amazing as it shows their mastery of their script and their character.

The build up of the story was slow but entertaining, nonetheless, thanks to the comic of the three maids.

They were obviously pointing out references to defend themselves (Marcoses) which was kind of a smirking moment for me - it wasnt because I doubt them or something but more of a "Okay they are being defensive on this part but go on."

The team tried to build up the story by "Chaptering" the whole plot which is I think is kind of in the infant stage of Philippine cinema, at least they tried, and I should give credit to them because it was in a unique way of directing/producing the film. Given the fact that our movie industry is falling apart because of the likes of mainstream tweetums drama cliche stories of Cardo Dalisay, Kim Chiu, Vice Ganda and the like.

Feels of the movie could be better. I guess it was just the filter of the picture.

There were scenes of some of news cuts. It was okay for references but again, it could be portrayed/edited better. But nevertheless, the cinematic feels is there.

The torches, the Mahjong, the nuns were better off omitted if possible. But it is their point of view so whether or not these were true, they left it for us to do more research if we wanted confirmation.

Acting: The three maids, were great especially Beverly Salviejo. Great Character!

Ella Cruz was really into it! I thought she's just one of those actresses who was just famous. But no, she can act. And she can perform really well!

Cesar Montano as always has always been a great actor. So thats just it.

Diego Loyzaga needs improvement. I can't wait for his lines to be finished.

Ruffa depicted Imelda just fine. Nothing much engagement with the film.

Finally, Christine Reyes. She went on full beast mode with this one. The acting was just overflowing but I guess that how they wanted to portray her.

Overall, come on guys. It's a film so just watch it. Be objective enough to give where proper credit is due and not just because of Historical Revisionism point of view. It gets old. Compare him to Hitler for all I care, but some of you watched Davinci Code, Hitler movies and Lucifer the TV show. I mean, come on.

P. S. Will watch Katips tomorrow and will leave a reply to that review as well.

Cheers.

DOES IS REVISE PHILIPPINE HISTORY??? DEFINITELY NOT. AS IN BIG BIG "NO". It doesn't change a thing about what we already know. The movie is not about showing who's right and wrong. It just showed the chaos and what was happening outside the palace and what was happening INSIDE the Malacañang at the same time. It never discredited any abuses nor any other claims. Instead, it just showed a new perspective and that is what was going on INSIDE the palace while every other thing is happening outside and in EDSA.

DOES IT MAKE PEOPLE SYMPATHIZE WITH THE MARCOSES? DOES IT MAKE PEOPLE SEE THE MARCOSES AS VICTIMS? NO. I don't think it intends to do that either. Everything depends on how every viewer takes everything in. It's an emotionally-packed movie and it just bombards you with everything. It bombards you with their "truth", their personal experiences, their emotions. It just literally gives you what these people felt and what they did during those last hours. Now, it's up for the viewers to decide whether or not they'd believe their story.

DOES IT PAINT LATE PRESIDENT CORY AQUINO IN A BAD LIGHT? NO. I don't think so. It just stated a normal reaction from a leader who thinks of Marcos Sr as her enemy. She wants him out of the country and so she did. I won't look at her like she's the bad one just because she wanted Marcos out of the Philippines.

AS FOR THE CONTROVERSIAL MAH-JONG SCENE...IT IS A METAPHOR. It just showed how politicians together with the "CHURCH" played their blocks for this EDSA Revolution. PLUS, FILIPINOS ARE NOT STUPID. Of course we know that Cory Aquino is really not playing Mahjong with her pink sisters during time of crisis. It's a given. Not just because we saw in the big screen that late pres. Cory and the nuns are playing means that they're really doing that at that time. We all know what to take as a symbolism, a metaphor and what to take literally.

IN VIEW HERE OF, ALL I CAN SAY IS...MAID IN MALACAÑANG IS A MUST WATCH!!!!! The family is crisis and all the characters are very relatable. Each of the viewers can see themselves in those characters, may it be as a father or mother or sister or brother or even as househelps who have been treated as a part of the family they've served for years. The music is powerful and very on point. The actors are all great!!! The lines are very very impactful especially the last part. No wonder why it will surely be a BLOCKBUSTER MOVIE!!! To everyone, WATCH IT!!!! IT IS ALL WORTH THE HYPE!!! VERY VERY WORTH IT!!!! KUDOS TO EVERYONE WHO MADE THIS MOVIE HAPPEN!!!

Family Movie: This is a great family movie. Philippine History was not revised thru this film entirely. Fantastistic movie: They may say this movie is a trash and not worthy but in fact it is not. It was a jaw dropping and a roller coaster of events happening to a family in times of a crisis .It is a storytelling a of a family on how they handle this kind of situation.

My child's POV (History taught on their school): As a parent born in 1980, I want my children to have their freedom of expression and we respect it because it is their rights. We watched it on the first day of the movie (Aug 3, 2022) so that we can experience the vibe of millions of Filipinos who are hunger for entertainment and excited to go out with their families after 2 years of fear, anxiety brought by pandemic. The movie MiM is a very family oriented movie, that's why it has a rating of PG. And we can assure that it is very understandable and remarkable in the minds of our little ones. Me and my husband together with my youngest (15yr old), really enjoyed our family time - we laugh, react and even hide our little tears while watching the movie. It really touched our hearts as a FATHER to his SON, a SON to his FATHER & MOTHER, a DAUGHTER to her FATHER, and an AMO to their KASAMBAHAYS, we don't even thought of any political motives and it doesn't enter our minds that it was a black propaganda againts the previous administrations after the Marcos regime. I am not a movie expert, but I have eyes to see what is beautiful or not, I have hands that can feel the hands of my child that touched me during scenes that might get her nervous or excited. And I have a heart that can feel the hurt, the fear, and the hopelessness of a family that was betrayed by their so-called friends, allies, supporters and even families. I can relate to that, because I even experienced that in real life. When we got home, I asked my child "so anak may nabago ba sa history nyo?" She said "wala naman po mommy". And that's from my child's point of view. And that's their freedom! Congrats to the writer and director Darryl Yap.

TO BE CLEAR: Yes I have my own political views and those close to me knows that. BUT, I have and will always respect people even if they have a diff political view with me. Admittedly, I have a love hate relationship with Darryl Yap's movies. Don't like Pornstar 2, Babaeng Walang Pakiramdam, Revirginized. Indifferent to Gluta, liked Pornstar, liked Jowable alot and truly AMAZED at Tililing. (All of which we have posts of as well) Had high hopes with this one but I really didn't know what to expect.

The story telling part was very well done. Same with the choice of music and scoring. Could have been so flat and boring because it was mostly talking among a few, emphasis on a few characters on a single location with a single topic. BUT, Biday, took control of this movie! There were a lot of powerful scenes and her involvement in those scenes, though actually minor and irrelevant and some made just to lighten the mood was SO ON POINT and FUNNY it made this movie that much more fun to watch! Truly unexpected and caught me off guard that made me laugh so hard.

The cast in general were really good, special mention to Christine Reyes, wow, Cesar Montano, wow, and BEVERLY SALVIEJO, WOW! Ella Cruz had one powerful great scene and hoped she did more.

8 of 10 for me. Was suppose to be a 9 but that cheap shot in the end was distasteful and merits a minus one, even if the telephone conversation (alone) was based on a documented interview. BUT, overall, something worth watching, specially because of Biday :D #wherecollectingisalifestyle.

Heart wrenching: Salute to all the character of Maid in Malacañang you did a great job. From the trailer to premier you nailed it. It's so tear jerking Movie.i love it!!! Please watch to your heart content and don't forget to bring your tissue with you.

A MUST SEE MOVIE!!!: This movie will surely give you lots of emotions. Scenes will make you laugh, cry, get mad, get scared, sympathize, empathize. Definitely a movie for the ages. An eye opener and a very heart warming film: This movie made me feel so sad about what happened to their family. I never knew that before. I am happy that I watched this film. It shows how the Philippine history I knew before was not the real truth. You will know what I mean once you watch it.

AN UNTOLD STORY OF A KNOWN FILIPINO FAMILY: As someone who ACTUALLY WATCHED the film, I believe, It would be better for someone like me (who have watched it) to comment or make a review about it.

The movie has A LOT going on, definitely worth your money. It is an "untold story of a known Filipino family", nowhere near how they call it: "historical revisionism", but I do agree with revising parts of our history if there is a need to, and clearly, there is.

It is well-made; the acting, the plot itself, the setting, the effects, the props/clothes, everything.

It made me cry and at the same time, it made me laugh. Now, if you'd like to feel the same thing, know the what's happening inside the Palace that time, and know the Marcoses better, watch #MAIDinMALACAÑANG.

Showing now in over 200 cinemas nationwide and SOON worldwide!

movie of the year: Most satisfying .. worth to watch... worth ur time and money a movie that full of emotion.. kudos to director daryll yap and all the artist involve on that movie.

Eye-opening scenes and a great family movie!!!: The movie is extremely meticulously narrated, and there is a lot of symbolism that will undoubtedly leave an impression on every audience. 72 hours in Malacanñang but still alot of story needed to be told.: The creative production of Sen. Imee and vision of Director Darryl Yap creating a story of how a person, family, a household would react in their most difficult time. The actors, sets, dialogs, and story blending into one gives us a time machine and feeling of whats happening behind what media, books, people wont show to the people for the past 37 years.

A family movie in time of crisis and the loyalty of their maids: This movie will make you cry and after crying will make you laugh again and again. Because chapter by chapter the movie will give you the moments of the family in malacanang under pressure. Their struggles to not to be hurt and to survive for that 72 hours. Their maid was loyal to them and want to fight back to protesters who want to go to the palace and up until now 1 of those maid is alive and still by the side of Madam Imelda Marcos. No historical revisionism. Just emotions of a family that we all can relate to. And also the struggles of those maid to serve and stay loyal to Marcos Family up until the end. And their is one special maid in the story that you need to know who. Love this film.

The Other Side of The Story: The other side of the story that is not known to many. A must-see family drama. Very relatable to common Filipino families. IT'S NOT REALLY AN HISTORICAL DISTORTION NOR A BIOPIC, IT'S JUST ALL ABOUT THE LAST DAYS OF THE MARCOSES IN MALACAÑANG DURING 1986 EDSA REVOLUTION: At first, we really thought or expect that it was historical distortion or revisionism of what really happened during the 1986 EDSA People Power Revolution. But we've surprised and dissapointed, disappointed because we thought there will be revisionism but they did not have that.

And here's my review about the movie, which is same as the reviews of Mr. Mark Perez Agullana.

Plot.

The movie as the trailer suggested it is about the few days of The Marcoses in Malacañan Palace from the personal account of their household helper or maid and the Maid in Malacañan Senator Imee R. Marcos. By watching this movie, it presented a view I rarely see, read or hear about the Marcoses. Of course, it touched politics but more than that it was a family drama, the other side of the villain most of us do not know through the eyes of those close to him. The story was told with mix of "truth" and "artistic license". It was fun, laughters and tears. The story was told in a clear simple manner that everyone can easily follow.

Themes and Tone The main theme of the movie for me is family than politics. It was made to entertain and educate as well. It is easy to spot on the funny and entertaining jokes inserted in the movie. It is also highlighting and presenting what are the obvious in politics and life - traitorship, allyship, trust, honesty, doing what is right, doing what is good, family connection, friendship and other values. But most importantly, it highlighted the most important unit of the society, the family and its importance especially in difficult times. It tells the importance of making up a decision and acting on it.

There are many symbolisms in the film like the conversation between Bonget and Imelda and how they will be able to return to the Philippines and to the power, great use of imagination. And of course, the most controversial scene of Cory played by Giselle Sanchez. That closing scene and the statement are great show of how Politics and Religion are playing the lives of many Filipinos, the fate of the nation and its wealth while they are lucky for having a seat of power. Until today this is true, in every election and important bills being pushed in the congress.

Acting and Characters I like how each character played their roles. Still, Cesar Montano is Cesar Montano. From Muro Ami to this film. I am thinking how difficult it maybe for Diego Loyzaga to act with his father. Great scene. I wish I have a conversation with my father on important matters in my life. I feel like ILoveRuffaG is not Ruffa with her like x100 very slow movement in the movie. But I like how she potrayed Imelda with so much grace, beauty and elegance. She is really different from who she really is. She matched and gave justice to the role. Ella Cruz is okay. Not too much, not less. But she really did great in her scene with Cesar convincing the father to move out. The three maids were really good. Karla Estrada and Beverly Salviejo were very funny in their scene which gave a balance to this dramatic movie. It was not OA. Of course, Christine Reyes who played the very important role, showed in the movie the acting you expect from her.

Direction Daryll Yap's signature story telling was very evident in the movie. It was simple, not complicated, not too fast and not to slow directing. It was almost a straightforward story telling with symbolisms in a funny way. There was a little tension.

Score The music chosen for each scene were matched perfectly to build the emotions and connect to the characters and story. I like the song choice.

Cinematography The camera movement especially during long walks of Imee is bit shaky, maybe budget or I am not certain if that was intentional. The various shots and angle were good. It is comparable to mainstream films at low budget. I like how the camera was moving in circular motion changing the position of the characters of Bonget and Imelda while they were talking. It depicted how their lives were turning up side down. The lines, the shot, the movement and acting were aligned. All actors were framed properly.

Production Design The costumes and props were good. They matched with the story, the setting and the characters.

Special Effects There's not much special effects used in the movie except the sound effects which are okay.

Editing The film was cleanly edited. The flow is consistent. The transitions used are very simple but effective alongside with the effects and music.

Pace The pace is neither slow nor fast. It was enough. Each scene is not dragging and arranged properly. It was like small episodes of the usual vincentiments film and combined as one.

Dialogue There are conversations that I really feel not needed and the movie will stand still. Oh well, there is really a good script.

Lessons There are many lessons you can take from the movie. It presented an alternative view of the existing truth about the freedom we are enjoying today. Does it change the way I view EDSA, Cory, FEM, Ramos, Juan Ponce Enrile, the Nuns, the Martial Law victims, the truth, the democracy and others? No. It just reaffirmed what I am already believing about FEM, Cory, Ramos, Johnny, the Marcos Family, the Aquino Family, the Nuns, the Martial Law Victims, the EDSA Rallyists and the Filipino People - they are all human beings neither good nor bad. That good or bad outcomes are based from each person's decisions and actions. The movie was good, but I expect more next time.

PS. Indeed, the crowd went applauded after watching the movie. I just want to understand those person who are full of hatred in this movie even the truth is always truth. And this kind of movie, was made from the creative minds and imaginations. Their situations are believable, but the drama or act? Hehehe only they know the truth.

Your political opinions are better said and heard in elections, not here.: A family in crisis trying to come to terms with events unfolding during a tumultuous time in history. The film, despite patently baseless allegations of "historical revisionism" by spineless critics, and farce, inorganic "reviews" by those seeking to resuscitate their defunct and decaying political capital, provides insight into the untold final moments of the Marcos family in Malacañang during the 1986 EDSA protests. No material misrepresentation of "known" historical facts were made in the film. I encourage you to see Maid in Malacañang for yourself to see how laughable and immature its film critics are. I should have rated this 9 stars myself but i have to compensate for the irrational and politically-charged reviews. Amazing movie: It's truly an amazing movie. It tells us the other side of the story straight from the people who were with the Marcoses. A family movie filled with laughter, sadness, fear and many more.

Superb Storytelling, Excellent Actors: Writer and Director Daryl Yap was effectively able to let the audience understand and feel what the Marcos Family went thru during their last 72 hours in Malacanang. It did not revise what happened in Edsa but showed the other side of the coin.

This film made us cry, laugh, cringe, hate and love. All the actors were excellent in portraying their roles, most especially the Maid in Malacanang.

I love how the story unfolded in chapters, more like so when you are reading a book, and I got to appreciate how each title was artistically appropriate. The development of the drama and the timing of the humor were perfect. It can be published in a book and can be even made more powerful in a theater production.

This movie made me appreciate my family even more and it reminds people how love and family can make us strong despite the pain and the difficulty.

Definitely a must-see for the whole family and for those who want to have a broader perspective of the truth.

Thought-provoking, remarkable, and hilarious - overall, entertaining!: I'd say 99% of the low rating reviews that the movie received came from people who have not watched the movie, I'll tell you why after I share my honest and objective review of the one of the most popular and controversial Filipino movies of 2022.

Most of these people are saying the movie twisted the usual narrative and that it revised the history by peddling lies about the Marcoses. The person who'd say just that is being too dramatic and is most likely a god who's all knowing of what actually happened inside the house and the minds of the Marcoses during the last 72 hours of its dynasty.

No one can really tell you what exactly happened in the last 72 hours as every person's perception of an event that took place in the past has his/her own version of that event. Say you interview 10 people from a single event, each one of those participants may have different version based on his/her perception, views, and beliefs. Hence, you can't say someone else's testimony or version of an event is "false" or "wrong". There is no absolute right or wrong - what's right for you may not be right for others, do not be all too self righteous.

However, this movie in particular is truly controversial as the movie apparently did not put the Marcoses in the bad light, which is something new to most people given how this last name is notorious for being the worst of the worst kinds of people - only if social media existed during the Marcos dynasty, back then, it was easy for powerful people to twist the minds and realities of the masses.

The theater in Cebu (SM Seaside) where I watched was i'd say was about 95% full, and the movie received a round of applause upon reaching the credits. If that doesn't make a movie good for you, then I do not know what is. Again, what's a good movie for you may not be good for the others viewers, and that's alright. As always, watch the movie before you rate it.
