Two thumbs up: Don't be fooled by the. Snowflake dilawans' review of this movie. Not only do they have no intention of seeing the movie (yet rated it low anyway) but they got so excited rating it ahead of its official theater release. That alone gives you a clue as to what kind of people this group are.

The movie is not an "attempt" to "revise history" or to "distort" it. The movie is simply a glimpse of how the Marcoses handled their situation inside Malacanang Palace as EDSA "people power" was going on outside their gate. It's how they struggled through the ordeal individually as a son/daughter, as a father, as a mother, as member of the extended family (the maids), and how they handled it as a family as well.

Sure there were scenes that can be thought of as provocative. They can be seen as a swipe to Cory and those who masterminded and staged PP but they were very few and far in between. Besides, the movie itself caters to a specific audience. It's for those who are sympathetic to the Marcoses so it's to be expected that it will play to its audience.

Anyway, this is more of a family drama more than anything else. It humanized the Marcoses. And it was done in a way that it did.not completely absolved them nor completely glorified them. Honestly, I don't know where the fear is coming from.

Anyway, it's refreshing to see a Filipino movie that is different from the usual.

This film can pioneer a revolution in the industry. Martial Law- the other side: The movie revolves around the last 72 hours of the Marcos family in the Malacañang Palace.

1. Why did FEM stay long in power?

It was merely showing things, as they unfold, through the eyes of the accused. They also showed footage and published interviews that backed-up the statements made by the characters. This movie opens up a lot of things for discussion and further examination. History, the same with any scientific claim, must react and change according to new evidence discovered, submitted or unearthed. I really think people should stop judging the film before they get a chance to watch it. They should also keep an open mind and let their curiousity be piqued.

Worth the watch - For open-minded viewers: It's a family drama with an excellent pinch of comic relief. Contrary to the "hate" it's getting from those who have not really watched it due to political leaning, this movie did deliver on entertainment value.

The actors performed surprisingly well. From the extras, "maids" and to the lead roles, kudos. Story telling was smooth and editing was masterfully stitched. Soundtrack, hands down. The director really made an effort to tell the story without pretense. It was raw.

Was there a historical revisionism? I didn't think so. My father had personal accounts of the ML and the story was already ingrained in me since childhood. So I think, (at least to my perspective) that this story was something else.

In the cinema, I do hear people being emotional from some scenes. Seeing some audience nearby my seat, trying to wipe their tears. I was also one of those. I was actually moved not because of the characters itself but on how the director and the actors made the story relatable to common people - family. It does make you realize how important it is to learn from experiences and that it's always wise to listen to your parents. Love - is the primordial factor of survival.

If some people wouldn't think about the baggage of what this movie is all about, then I think it deserve better scores.

Then the internet rise.

Iam now 37 years old, little by little,I'm questioning myself. Is the story about the EDSA and Martial law are correct,creditable and factual?

I started searching. Books by books. Article by article.

Then I realized, the history about it,which I've known since elementary was just a piece of trash.

I was living in a factual lies!

2016,BBM(Ferdinand Marcos Jr.) run the Vice Presidential seats but lost. From then on, I told to my self that I will support them. Not because what I have learned about them,but on what they can do in order to lead the Filipino people.

6 years gone past and he run again but for the highest post. And tremendously won the heart of 31m Filipinos by landslide. Why? Redeeming 30+ years of damage: I have lived my life from the very start of martial law and I am now approaching my senior years.

All along, I already knew the stories portrayed in this movie so none of these are new or surprising to me since I have followed these events in 1986 on tv, radio, newspapers and further reading.

And yet, I just have to shed tears for myself and my fellow Filipinos while watching Maid in Malacanang.

Great acting, story telling and directing. We can all relate to this movie if we watch it with an open mind and no political baggage.

Bottomline for me, if I were to categorize it, is that this is a movie about a family in the eyes of a family member and extended household who were in the throes of revolutionary hopelessness and filled with drama (not sensational or over the top like what we see in our soap operas) and light comic relief.

The soundtrack was equally moving and has been dwelling in my mind, rent-free.

Those 30+ years, sad to say, were wasted time for what could have been a truly great nation of and for the Filipinos.

Damage has and will continue to be done to the mindset of Filipinos from mind-conditioning and brainwashing by schools, the communists, the catholic church and the biased mainstream media which are still controlled by oligarchs and US puppets.

They have done this for the last 50+years and has institutionalized this bias since 1986.

These evil collusions will continue to wreak havoc if we don't deepen our understanding of the true state of this nation and the forces that are acting against the common good of the Filipinos.

I don't see any attempt to revise history.

Story was told as it happened from first hand experience and personal perspectives.

The movie serves its purpose in broadening the mindset and consciousness for nation building.

With Knowledge, Understanding and Unity, Filipinos will rise to true greatness.

Let's make it happen!

Emotion-triggering, tears and laughter: Despite all the fuss about this film, I went to watch it with an open mind. It could go either way but it did not disappoint. I liked that the movie was broken down into chapters. I liked the dynamic of the family, it's just like a normal family who goes through traumatic events. I mean, how is it not traumatic when there are so many death threats. The pacing is easy to digest, I love the details that were of the era. 

The biggest take away I have is that, not everything is as media portrays it. Which is very rampant even to this date. It only solidifies all the stories I heard from my 79 year old father who lived and thrived. He always shared stories of life back in the day. The narrative over the past 34 years have been the same, it's old and tired. The narrative has been broken. I think it's high time to hear the other side, which is weird because there are a few who are against it? Why? Even during a trial, there's prosecution and defense. We werent allowed to hear the defense side of things, it's due time to hear the other side. Also, if those years were truly the worst of the times, how come some of the very crucial hospitals that were made then are still very useful these days? What's even more boggling is that those who wished to overthrow then president and promised better lives for Filipinos did the exact opposite of what they promised the people? How come instead of making our lives better it became stagnant and even went downhill? Where is the improvement they promised? Heart center, lung center, and kidney institute were not improved and there werent any creation of additional public hospitals like those anymore. Those facilities that were built in that "dark era" are still functional to this date. Overrun as they are, they help the common citizen. These are some of the things that broke the opposing narrative. We refuse to be led to believe the holier-than-thou narrative. It's overused and tired. The hypocrisy is blatant and we no longer stand beside it.

The movie showcases amazing acting from very good artists, it'll trigger so many emotions in the audience no matter your age or sex. At the end of the day, it is an imagining of the last 72 hours in Malacañang in 1986. It is a movie, democracy is for everyone not for a select few. This movie should be watched those who bash it have an alternate agenda and it's petty.

I Didn't Like It But Definitely Entertaining: So what are my thoughts about Maid In Malacañang.

This is a non paid review for this film.

Unlike trolls who reviewed this film and gave this bad marks without watching it.

So to start.

I don't like it. But read along before you attack with torches and hurl insults.

Here are reasons why. (Warning : Few Spoilers)

This is not a historical movie. If you want to see something stronger, then watch Brocka's banned movie or actual news footage. Not a movie told from the perspective of the producer, the director or the award giving bodies.

If you are expecting a revisionist movie like dispelling rumours about the Marcoses excesses and opulence, this is not for you. It doesn't hide their wealth and their control of people around them - from the luxury-wearing zero-gravity moving Imelda, to the scary bossy angered Imee, the party going camou-wearing brave-wanting Bonget. No sugar coating here - they are revealed as spoiled people.

It doesn't portray the Marcoses as the bravest souls as they show here how they spiraled to their fears and frustrations, the latter shown by former President FEM himself. If you are expecting them to be portrayed here as a blameless hero family, they aren't as even Irene

It doesn't show the Marcoses as the most powerful family in the country as they too failed to save their entire extended household (meaning those who lived long with them in the palace). The mahjong scene that irked many before the actual showing revealed the figures who were more powerful, and I emphasize, were as it is passe. And it is not the one who sat at the mahjong table but the bigger entity some tried to represent mockingly.

It didn't show the atrocities during Martial Law nor it depicted further the evil side of many politicians some have come to worship for decades. Nor did it tackle the roots of what made Martial Law to be declared.

It didn't utilise more some actors like Elizabeth Oropesa, the controversial Ella Cruz and even the most hated actress now for portraying the symbolic yellow wearing saint, Gieselle Sanchez. I feel like some scenes really got stolen much by the superb timing and acting of Beverly Salviejo aka Manang Biday.

But it did reveal some things that would make more people ponder, especially with the "what ifs". Highly entertaining as was the movie, I am left with questions after seeing it as the pieces still don't feel complete. With many puzzle pieces hidden before like actual video clips of how the palace was stormed and yes, burned (as there are actual reports to such in the news), the actual announcements to join EDSA uprising (I wish they put recordings of those actual announcements of Sin calling the faithful), to the big reveal for some that Marcoses were aimed to be killed by friends and some organised people, I can't help but ponder is the running time enough for film or is this better a series?

Some things are made clear here though.

First, and I won't be apologetic. This is a middle finger movie to Ramos who died days before the movie was shown. Maybe he chose to die before his humiliation can be revealed that he was indeed part of planners to kill off the first family. I know BBM paid respects but the Maid in Malacañang didn't and I understand her for that.

This is also a big middle finger movie to family and friends who betray us for politics. Darryl never shies away from controversy and arguments. With the 2022 election campaign being hailed as the most toxic we experienced (and maybe the worst of all time). The lines hit hard that you eat on the same plate with people who wish you dead. Sadly, toxicity is shared on the plate.

This is not a hate film though. In fact, it is a beautifully crafted melodrama with light touches of humor and reference to 80s, to telenovelas and even PRRD's expletives. The music was superb, the pacing mostly on point but always easy to follow and the acting delivered credibly by everyone in the main cast. If Cesar Montano and Beverly Salviejo don't get awards here, we know some directors probably thought to award it to someone else and found their own reflections.

Darryl also is masterful in creating memorable lines like how he delivered with his notoriously popular LenLen series. My dad kept repeating some of the lines he remembered and I of course love villains so you know whose I remember the most. Add the symbolisms, references and mild swearing he put may look or sound cliche for some but those are reminders that this movie is not perfect nor the people shown in it. It doesn't lie like others hailing their own as absolute truth and true masterpiece that must be seen again (and I say again as not much watched the first run, it wouldn't earn either with a re-run if not put side by side with Maid in Malacañang). It doesn't lie that it is not without creative liberties meant to stir emotions at almost every chapter as they hit the right nerves at most points.

Maid in Malacañang is not a movie made to justify lies as others claim it would be. Rather, it presents itself as a vulnerable piece prone to dissection - hence chapters. It is highly entertaining as it is thought provoking, tear inducing, BP raising, heart warming.

So I don't like it.

I love it.

PS the final mahjong scene looks funny in the trailers but it is actually a sinister dark energy filled take, from the daunting music which reminds of The Omen, to the evil spewed out lines to the closing of hands playing with yellows. A promotion of what was to come. Darryl should make a horror film continuation about this. :P.

I came out thinking of love and power after laughing and tearing up on the various chapters of the movie. Love being power in itself. The movie was love of parents, siblings, workers who remained loyal until the end, love of self (masama ba akong tao?), people who surrounded those in power and love of country. Love after all is power.

It has often been said, "Love is Light, that enlightens those who give and receive it. Love is gravity, because it makes some people feel attracted to others. Love is power, because it multiplies the best we have, and allows humanity not to be extinguished in their blind selfishness. Love unfolds and reveals."

I hosted a private screening of #MIM last 9 August. I carefully selected the audience ensuring a generational mix. There are six (6) generations: Baby Boomers: born 1946 to 1964; Generation Jones: born 1955 to 1965; Generation X: born1 965 to 1980; Xennials: born 1977 to 1983; Millennials: born 1981 to 1996; Generation Z: born 1997 or after and Generation Alpha: born 2010 or after. X. Only Generation Alpha was not represented. A total of 56 individuals watched #MIM.

There was no revisionism made. It provided the 72 hours on the other side of the proverbial fence, the side of the Marcoses which were never really made clear to all Filipinos. The side I hated and never crossed in my youthful years. But a leader I knew from grade school to college. He was my only president for my first 23 years.

Of course I didn't know the POV of the three (3) maids but certainly knew of Sen. Imee Marcos' role as "mayordoma" - she was after all the assistant of her father, being the eldest and more knowledgeable than the other siblings.

MiM reinforced the characterizations I learned of Imee Marcos and Bongbong Marcos growing up. There was no sugarcoating on those two. What got my attention was that of the youngest, Irene Marcos. She was never political. She was always the sweet girl with a ready smile. That scene of Irene Marcos with the father was gut wrenching. Was there creative license there? I don't know because Irene Marcos has never been in the public eye. But that scene summed up what to be in government meant, what to hold power and how to deal with people wanting more. Meron bang mabuting pamahalaan is still ringing.

Clearly the sibling rivalry was there. Clearly, Imee was her father's daughter and Bongbong was the mama's boy. On point was a strong Imee and a gentle and low-key Bongbong. The moorings of the son was palpable in the scenes with the eldest, father and mother. Interesting that the journal page on Bongbong had an extended play with FM saying he believed in his son despite being a spoiled brat, the son after all was out to secure the support of the father. In politics, the namesake will always have that internal doubt (am I worthy of the name? Can I be better than my father? Could I achieve even just an inch of what he has done?). I have seen that internal debates with fathers and sons in the world of politics.

The scene of loyalists remaining in the palace wearing yellow and doing the L sign were just stories I heard from friends who joined the march to Malacanang on that night. "May mga tao kaming nadatnan pero pro-Aquino." I remembered the trashing, the bringing out of souvenirs. I myself had a piece of the barbed wire but can't recall where it is today...

Ang "kasaysayan ay chismis"? Puede pero sa ilang dekadang pagsasaliksik at paghahanap ng katotohanan, puede and chismis ay nagkakaruon ng ugat at yumayabong hanggat may nagiibang daloy para ito muling baguhin. Hindi natutulog ang kasaysayan. Ito ay umiikot kung may kontrang daluyan ng punto o pangyayari na uusig sa ating kinagisnan.

Darryl Yap knows the public pulse so well. He intertwined happy and sad; comedic relief in a hot confrontation; the power of the moment and the internal questions one get to ask about how to love a country are all in the film. Sometimes, its takes a very ordinary view by maids that we discover the real narrative at the back of certain events. They may not sit well for some but it has to be told.

Were the Marcoses placed in a different light after MiM? Yes, because we saw their humanity and no, because the final chapter has yet to be written. As a wise man said to me after the film, it would be better to see who instigated all these things. "Where is Joma in all these?"

MiM also confirmed the role of a foreign power in getting the Marcoses out. They were escorted and just by a call, they were rerouted. I again remember a favorite adage: "In politics, nothing happens by accident. If it does, you can bet it was planned that way."

The character I loved in this film was Manang Biday. For someone who did not know how to swim, maybe she survived her plight because she drank a lot from the Pasig River .

Sometimes ordinary people hold the keys to where the mighty will soar or land head on. Often, they take the calumny to heart and that's what loyalists are made of. ###

MY PERSONAL MESSAGE: In this film, you will see how unjust these people went, but at the same time, how they deserved justice in the present time.

Remember, the Truth always will be revealed, one way or the other, maybe now or sooner. Whether you like it or not, Justice will prevail. It does not mean many people will believe and accept, but the Marcoses demonstrated that they still continued even if there are circumstances around them.

Haters out there, even if the elections are finished, do you even think the Marcoses will fail this time? No matter how much energy you put on hating the Marcoses, it would be useless. But it does not mean I hate you.

As a Filipino, can we all please stop all of this. Can we all move on? What would happen to the Philippines if we keep being divided? As a Filipino, I request that we must continue to prosper more, rather than being stuck talking about this history. It is time to start a new beginning.

My all time favorite Filipino film!: When It hit USA theaters, I was scrambling to find the nearest theater I could see it from East Tennessee, and it was in Virginia, so I was contemplating to drive or fly all the way, and decided to take air travel just to see this film, and after seeing it, it didn't disappoint and well deserved trip as well! SUPER BLOCK BUSTER FILIPINO MOVIE OF THE YEAR AFTER PANDEMIC: THE EMPEROR'S SWINDLER: A SPOILER-FREE REVIEW OF DARRYL YAP'S MAID IN MALACAÑANG BY SASS ROGANDO SASSOT

I have watched Darry Yap's other films - Jowables, Pornstar series, and Revirginized. What I noticed in those films is Yap's storytelling: he begins strong, then somewhere in the story he rushes to reach a denouement. Maid in Malacañang (MiM) is a different Yap.

Nothing felt rushed, the storytelling progressed like an onion being peeled delicately. Yap peeled MiM so delicately in its intricate layers, letting the audience shed tears as each layer unravelled, without emotionally manipulating them to do so.

And like in his other films, Yap combined drama and comedy - this time, seamlessly. There's still the usual preachy parts, like in his other films - this time, integrated so well as a narrative device, rather than as a cop out from the labor of story development.

As an ensemble, the cast is skilfully selected.

Cesar Montano is a Bernini sculpture: the minutest detail of his acting is Ferdinand E. Marcos. Diego Loyzaga is spot on in his portrayal of President BBM's coming of age moment. Real-life father and son, Cesar and Diego's confrontation scene is like watching a masterclass in acting.

Ruffa Guttierez's elegant acting unveiled Imelda, as a mother, beneath all the glamor. Ella Cruz as Irene Marcos tells us she has a bright future in Philippine cinema.

The three maids: Karla Estrada's comedic timing is masterfully delivered. Elizabeth Oropesa is timeless. Even when she's just standing, she makes you believe. Beverly Salviejo deserves a standing ovation for every scene: Give her her own full-length film. One never wastes a juggernaut like her! Even if there are 24 characters in a film, just cast Salviejo, and she would be able to persuade you that there were 24 different actors.

Now...Cristine Reyes as Imee Marcos. She does not deserve an acting award. Reyes must be given a monument. Rename NAIA, EDSA, the West Philippine Sea after her -- I don't care. Reyes, like Montano, is a Bernini sculpture: even when she is deep in thought, she is giving us Imee Marcos. If Reyes could top her acting prowess in MiM, name an entire galaxy after her.

As the film reached its denouement, I cursed: "Potaena ka Darryl Yap!!!! Brilliantly wicked!"

The Emperor's New Clothes told the story of the swindlers who made a fool of an emperor and his ministers. They promised to weave the finest cloth for the emperor, and whoever wouldn't be able to see it is unusually stupid. Unusually stupid - that's how enfant terrible Yap made everyone who thinks so highly of themselves looked like with his most brilliant work to date.

MiM's real plot isn't in the film itself. This is one of the rare instances where the real plot developed after the film has been promoted publicly. In this sense, MiM is just a subplot. The main plot is the one - consciously or unconsciously - written by Yap: The mass hysteria of people addicted to their victimhood - real or imagined, reacting to the film they never watched. Yap directed a satire -- and it's not MiM. If you're as alert as the innocent child in The Emperor's New Clothes, you will easily spot the nakedness of the Emperor, his ministers who lost the plot, and the swindlers who wove the finest golden cloth worn by history.

Must watch for every Filipino: This is a movie about the last 72 hrs of the Marcos family in Malacanan before the Liberal Party took over.

The story tackles the question: "How was the Marcos family while EDSA revolution was going on?" I cannot remember this topic being discussed in any history class nor in any "special feature" telenovela nor in any movie at that.

Previously made films or dramas always celebrated how the Aquinos were supposedly the heroes of Philippine democracy.

No other film in the contemporary time had tackled the story of Maid in Malacanan. And for that alone, I think this is a must watch for every Filipino, whatever political inclination you may have.

And if you will be watching, always keep in mind that this is a movie. For issues regarding "matter of fact", it would still be prudent to do your own research. This movie will definitely stimulate your interest in Philippine history. It will make you realize that perhaps your history lessons back in your elementary/high school days might actually be just a one-sided story.

My reviews for MIM: I've watched "Maid in Malacañang" last Aug.3 in a fully-packed at SM Cinema SMBF.

There is nothing revisionist about what happened in the critical days of EDSA, and absolutely nothing about Martial Law or the attempt to redifine it.

A Surprisingly Good Movie with Roman Catholic Themes: A surprisingly good movie, considering the sensitive subject matter! Genuine characterizations of the Marcos family, including their personality flaws, and a nice balance of drama and humor. Not at all revisionist, as the contents are mainly interpersonal events between the Marcos family and household staff, and TV news footage. Looking forward to the sequel.

There are a lot of Christian and Roman Catholic themes in the movie. I will not mention these in my review to avoid spoiling the movie. These themes become more evident on the second or third viewing. Observe the way the characters are presented visually. Also listen carefully to what they say, especially their choice of words. Observe things that are present around the characters.

The genre of the movie is definitely political, with the objective of humanizing the Marcos political family. This is good, because the Marcos family are human beings, and the movie is telling this truth. But I think the movie at its core, is deeply Roman Catholic, and uses the story of the Marcos family to communicate spiritual truths.

I did not give the movie the highest rating because there are some parts of the movie that "tell you" rather than "show you" through action and character development. But it is not easy to see this because the acting is so good. You are able to lose yourself in the world of the Marcos family during their final days in power, and we also care about the characters so much that we do not clearly discern the screenplay writer "preaching to you".

A lot of criticism about the movie comes from the final scene where Cory Aquino is playing Mahjong with some nuns, as they say this did not happen, and so give this final scene as an example of historical revisionism. However, what Cory was doing at the time is not historically significant. The critics miss what is being communicated in this scene at a spiritual level. Observe closely the altar next to the Mahjong table. Do you notice anything odd? What is the position of Cory Aquino relative to the altar? Do you notice anything odd about the nuns? If you see the spiritual theme being presented, then now you might have something significant to be upset about, after you get over the initial shock.

Enjoy the movie. It gets better with every viewing.

I have created a vlog reviewing this movie in my BitChute Channel: "Prepare For Departure". It is a spoiler review, so I recommend that you watch the movie first.

It's very easy just to rely on what's out there already in terms of historical documentation and documentaries on the Marcos era and those days as well as the so called EDSA revolution, but what we don't know is what it was really like for those present with the family themselves, what were there feelings, emotional responses and so much more. This movie and that era has been brought to life through the excellent storytelling of Philippine director, Darryl Yap. Review from someone who watched the movie: The movie is a must watch. Moving politics aside, I love it. No historical distortion happened, this was just the last 72 hours of the Marco's in the palace.

An absolute masterpiece: It was the first time in my entire life that a movie had such a profound impact on me from beginning to end.

The chapters are their entirety highlights. In the movie, each character has a standout moment.

1. The scene between Marcos Sr. And MarcosJr. Is excellent and ends with some humor.

2. I was deeply moved by the interaction between Irene and Marcos Sr. Irene's speech reflects her anguish very viscerally.

3. Imelda and Marcos Jr. Scene also made me shiver, and the scene where Imelda recognizes her jewelry and shoes captivated me. In the end, one of the maids sings the background music, and Biday is hilarious.

4. I was moved by the scene between Marcos Sr. And Imee in which he declared Imee to be his favorite and most trusted child.

5. But it was the sight with all the house staff and security officers that moved me and practically shed a tear to my eye. The three main maids address the entire staff in this scenario in order to inform them of the apparent departure of the first family. I was only able to control myself because I was sitting next to another viewer. But if I'm by myself, I imagine I'll be sobbing uncontrollably.

6. The final chapter, in which the servants lamented their exile with the family but were forced to use a piece of yellow clothing from Imelda's closet, is similarly heartbreaking.

Even as I write this review, I can't stop crying. The movie is a true masterpiece and magnificent. I'll watch this movie again, I swear.

true story: The movie is actually a family dramedy. If there is one thing that I find problematic, it is the stereotypical typecasting, once again, of maids becoming the sources of comic relief. But certainly, it is hard not to be amazed by Yap's masterful weaving in of humor as a punchline, most vividly represented by that emotionally charged confrontation between father and son Ferdinand Marcos Sr. And Jr., played by real father and son Cesar Montano and Diego Loyzaga, capped by the tiptoeing Biday, ably played by veteran comedian Beverly Salviejo. It was seen again in that touching dramatic silent monologue of Imelda Marcos played by Ruffa Gutierrez as she bid goodbye to her material possessions of gowns and shoes, taking only small mementos and love letters her husband Ferdie sent her, to the tune of that iconic 'Dahil Sa Iyo,' which turned out to be not a soundtrack but Biday, again, belting out her own aria as she was dusting a flower vase.

On a larger scale, the entire movie was actually a wicked punchline to rudely douse water ON the misplaced fears, the ruckus and the noise, about this movie becoming a monumental sacrilege to the altars of historical purity. There is nothing in this movie that actually distorts, revises, or replaces what we already know. This is not Yap and Viva Films trying to assault history with outlandish claims, but simply a dramatic, and sometimes hilarious, representation of a powerful family at their most vulnerable, most defeated state as they faced their imminent downfall.

It is the story of an eldest daughter, a role excellently enacted by Cristine Reyes playing Senator Marcos who struggled to lead a family in the throes of collapse, trying to hold it together. It is the story of a son, poignantly played by Loyzaga as the young President Ferdinand Marcos Jr., trying to make his father proud, trying to prove that he can be more than the party animal with whom his father expressed disappointment. It is the story of youngest daughter Irene Marcos Araneta played by Ella Cruz pleading with her father, and whose lines in the movie embodied a summary of the entire political career of her father.

Some people took note of the absence of any reference to the actual reasons why EDSA took place, and count this as a deficiency of the movie. What they missed is that this movie is less a historical account of EDSA, or the political downfall of the Marcoses, but a family drama to reveal the stories behind the façade of the presidential palace. Ella Cruz's character of Irene summed up what can possibly be said about the rule of her father - that his government was not perfect, and that he lost control of it and his people, many of whom betrayed him. These are factual claims.

There is no deliberate attempt to radically alter facts. Instead, what is given space is to provide the Marcos narrative a voice, and for the audience to form their own interpretations. The scene of the stash of cash at the beginning of the movie is perfect imagery that captured this. It establishes the fact that indeed there were boxes full of undistributed cash, which many would interpret as money intended to buy voters in the 1986 snap elections, but the character representing Senator Marcos rationalized it as payment for people who actually worked for the Marcos campaign. It was left to the viewers to form their own conclusions as to which narrative we will believe.

The much talked about, and bashed scene, of former president Corazon Aquino playing mahjong with nuns, who incidentally are clearly represented not as the Carmelite sisters, is actually an artistic and symbolic representation, following another symbolic scene where Ferdinand and Imelda waltzed while Malacañang was being attacked by a mob. If there is one moment where Yap made a political commentary, it would be in this symbolic representation of the political elites playing with the Church during EDSA. And no one can dispute that indeed the Church played a crucial role there.

This movie is not about revising history but about humanizing the Marcoses at their most vulnerable and weakest. This is something that cannot be denied by anyone, tyrant or otherwise. It doesn't change what they did or failed to do.

If there is another important fact that this movie revealed, it is that aside from the Marcoses there were others in Malacañang when it fell. These were the people who served them as guards and maids, who for so long were invisible, but finally were given a voice in this film.

In the end, the politics of this film is less seen in its content but more in how it has been received. It is like an RT-PCR test that would reveal whether we are positive with partisan prejudice, or negative and tolerant of other voices.

And even just a single clip on social media still gave me chills. I hope people from the other side watch the movie too. Kristine reyes, Cesar Montano, Ella Cruz made me cry. Beverly Salviejo made me laugh. Kudos to Direk Darryl and Viva films for this masterpiece movie we millennials are craving for.

Worth Watching: This is a good story from the other side of the spectrum which gives audience a chance to veer away from the long standing narrative of EDSA.

Direk Yap did not hide the real truth behind MIM. In fact, he is transparent declaring in a recent interview that, "This is a family in crisis film..." and is to be appreciated from the perspective of the maids, primarily the three Yayas - Biday (Beverly Salviejo), Lucy (Elizabeth Oropesa), and Santa (Karla Estrada). He also did not conceal the fact that the Marcos family had a direct hand in the making of the film, admitting in the same interview that Senator Imee Marcos deleted some from the original script, added some of her own, and approved the final script. Senator Imee Marcos is also the Executive Producer. It is in these regards that those behind MIM are honest and transparent as to the intentions of the movie.

And yeah, the number of ratings gives justice that this movie is indeed worth watching for Filipinos.

The last 72 hrs....: If you're expecting a political thriller or a historical biopic, this is not it.

While based on true accounts, this is not about flipping the EDSA narrative at all. It is not to glorify the first family nor to make them heroes. So all the fuss about historical revisionism as far as we can see, is much ado about nothing.

What you'll get instead is a powerful tearjerker that exposes the Marcoses at their most vulnerable - during their last 72 hours in Malacañang. Even if you're apathetic about the Marcoses, you will still be moved by how Direk Darryl Yap. Is the film perfect? That's too generous of a statement. But it's very well-done.

The film is not a hagiography of the Marcoses but it shows them in a more humane light without completely absolving them of their sins.

It is a story of family, of love, and of hope. And that's something we can all root for..

Good: RECIPEClassic Bananas Foster

By Poppy Tooker Fine Cooking Issue 106

Scott Phillips

(6 ratings)Read Reviews

Save to Recipe Box

Print

Add Recipe Note

Servings: six to eight.

Created at Brennan's restaurant in New Orleans in 1951, this classic dessert was named after loyal customer Richard Foster. Firm, ripe bananas are sautéed in a rum-infused caramel sauce, then flambéed in front of diners and spooned over vanilla ice cream. For extra pyrotechnics, throw a pinch of cinnamon onto the sauce as it flames.

Read the Test Kitchen blog for tips on flambéing safely.

Ingredients2 oz. (4 Tbs.) unsalted butter1 cup lightly packed dark brown sugar1/2 tsp. Ground cinnamon1/4 cup banana liqueur4 firm-ripe bananas, peeled, halved lengthwise, then halved crosswise1/4 cup amber rum, such as Old New Orleans or Goslings1 pint vanilla ice cream

Nutritional Information

PreparationIn a 12-inch skillet, melt the butter over medium heat. Stir in the brown sugar and cinnamon and cook until moist, about 1 minute. Add the banana liqueur and cook, stirring continuously, until the grainy texture disappears and the mixture rolls off the spoon in a steady stream, 1 to 2 minutes. Put the banana quarters rounded side down in the pan. Cook until the bananas begin to soften, 2 to 3 minutes.

Turn the bananas onto their flat sides. Remove the pan from the heat and pour in the rum. Set the pan over high heat and carefully ignite the rum with a long match or grill lighter. Gently shake the pan until the flame subsides. Remove from the heat.

Place a generous scoop of ice cream in 6 to 8 individual heatproof dessert bowls. Arrange 2 to 3 pieces of sautéed banana around each scoop of ice cream. Spoon on the sauce and serve immediately.

I pray that they do very well for the country so the "yellow/pink party" will NEVER be back in power.

2022 MOVIE OF THE YEAR!!!: This is touched my heart all the way from beginning to end! NO REVISIONS AT ALL! This depicts the treacherous AQUINO REGIME and how the got their power to the Filipino people. A must seen movie for every Filipino. Ferdinand Marcos is true hero, not only for the Filipino people; but for his family as well. Congratulations to the cast and crew.

made an account just for this!: I should've watched this sooner.

Everything was great including the cinematography and writing. The opening gave so much nostalgia for the 80s even though I'm a Gen Z. Tons of references, props and historical videos to back it up. The comedy is very cheesy but that also applies to every Filipino movie ever.

One complaint I have is the forced dialogue and political potshots but I don't really care that much because.

1. The plot is contained in only 72 hours

2. This was made in the middle of the election where everyone was in "war mode"

FACT OR FICTION? (SPOILER)

There are some elements that are fact and fiction but the history is 100% FACT. U. S News articles back then showed the extent of the military coup where Malacañang was being peppered with rockets. The protest being violent was also true as there's no such thing as a "peaceful protest" and the movie even shows news clips of brawls between Marcos and Aquino supporters.

I saw a negative reviewer here that claimed the maids were just fictional comic relief. The same reviewer admitted that they only watched 30 minutes of the film before storming out of the cinema in anger. This is just false.

The big reveal at the end was revealing that these 3 maids were actually real people. One even sadly passed away just two weeks after the events. Almost every Malacañang staff loved the Marcoses and it's a commendable Filipino trait as maids are always treated as part of the family.

So the history is actually factual, so where's the fiction?

Opinion: Personally I feel that Imee's entire character is fiction. As she heavily contributed to this film, it feels as though this is what she wanted it to have been rather than what actually happened.

In the film, Imee is treated as the leader of the household that even her parents can depend on. But witnessing the dynamics of older Ilocano households and even in Bongbong Marcos' own words, the Parents are never questioned and they lead the family by themselves.

WHY THE RATING?

As stated, my only problems were two elements so 8/10 but overall, it was enjoyable to watch.

The solemn scenes are beautifully intermixed with the humorous scenes. It doesn't follow the Filipino extreme like making us think someone's dead only to reveal that they were sleeping. It knows when to put a joke and not interrupt the pacing.

The scenes were also heavy. Props to the actors for the performance especially during my favorite scene "Ilocos o Leyte" where Imee has a mental breakdown of paranoia after finding out the severity of the situation.

I highly encourage watching with your family (16+) as it's more of a family film than a historical film. Seeing your parents relate to the 80's references makes you feel like your bonding with them and the theme of the entire film is a lesson on how strong family bonds always prevail over petty political fights.

Straight from the Fact!: Been watching Most of documentaries specially the Edsa event, and yes it was an unpleasant one, but what we know is just a ONE SIDED one.

Now i saw a lot, as in LOTS of supporting documents that are now binding to each other (the missing piece not shown by the media before). Also some of my titos and titas are more aware of the EDSA REVOLUTION events aside from the biased media telling me that the events are tailored.

The movie really showcase the other piece that are kept 37 years ago, specially inside the Malacañang Palace. Well documented and the actors/actress selection are excellent! Big clap for the director of this film! It was a masterpiece, indeed compare to other movies that are pure politics (self given awards) but NOT that great at all.

A must-to-see-movie!: Very unorthodox in handling both familial and political issues without compromising every element of film-making. Started to watch Yap's daring and vulgar approach in his previous movies and this is one , I would say deserves a 2-thumbs up.

SOBRANG GANDA: First time I've watch a Filipino film with excitement. Not really a fan of country's film but this movie set the bar of a good filipino film. Maybe because of the hype in social media influences me to take a look to this masterpiece. I was not disappointed. I did not expect it to be tearjerking film. It is just a family drama. You can relate to it because it is so common where when your family is in crisis, what you/charatcters in a family usually do during those time? The film portrait the Marcos is like a common family. They struggle! Kudos to the director for this art.

Balanced, not political at all!!: A family oriented movie! A must see movie. No distortion of history. Go watch and know the other side of history, the real story provided by the Marcoses. The historic last moments of Apo Marcos. Very smart, clever and harmless film by Darryl Yap. Christine Reyes, Cesar Montano, Ella Cruz, Diego Loyzaga, Ruffa Gutierrez, and the three maids, Elizabeth Oropeza, Karla Estrada and Beverly were all awesome artists. I cried, I laughed, I got upset, mad. As what the three maids in Malacañang said, the 1986 revolution was peaceful because the Marcoses didn't retaliate. The Marcoses didn't want violence, pain, and death.

A Master Piece!!!: A true masterpiece. A story about a family. Drama. Suspense. Love. Respect. A genuine Filipino story.

Only narrow-minded people and bitter losers despise this wonderful film.

The movie isn't a total rotten fruit but a lot of things need improvement!: Just watched Maid in Malacañang a couple of days ago. This is my first time to write a movie review and since I have no expertise in anything related to film production and writing stories, take this as a piece from an ordinary moviegoer. You might come across some strange expressions here, so I'm sorry in advance.

TECHNICAL STUFF. Whether it's the cinema's systems or the film's audio mixing, I found the sound so terrible that it affected my experience during the entire time. It was too loud that I had to cover my ears sometimes, even more for the moments when Cristine Reyes as Imee was shouting. And the balance between dialogue and music wasn't great; the Nosi Ba Lasi song didn't fit in well. And I wanted to enjoy the song naman while following the scenes. Another thing is the text. Did they make the text switch too soon or am I just a slow reader. I think it was too fast, and was part of my thought about the story feeling so rushed.

MUSIC. Nosi Ba Lasi is the theme song of the film. I didn't pay attention to the lyrics (never listened to the song before) but this version of Sampaguita's song did give some melancholic feeling to the story. Also I wished the background music wasn't so plain. I'm a sucker for movie soundtracks. The music score should have a unique identity.. It wasn't memorable. Also the sound of plucking strings during the maids' scenes felt pretentious. Didn't fit in with the sound style of the film.

CAST AND CHARACTERS. Okay, so I know nothing about the personalities of the family, so I wanted to see how the film would portray them whether it's assuming we already know the kind of people they are or it's gonna introduce them to us as if they're new (of course, accompanied with the knowledge this film is about the presidential family living at the Palace). I'm on the latter. I think Imee's introduction was good because I got to know her as this woman who's always moving, got a lot on her mind. When she gets back to the Palace, she's shown as the person most concerned about matters at home. I would be disappointed too if my siblings don't know what to do with their responsibilities haha. So I got the impression that the story would focus more on her development but the film dropped her in the middle of it. Irene, Imelda, and Bongbong suddenly got scenes of their own when I didn't really get to know them before that. (And clearly the father Ferdinand is a secondary character). Like, okay, I didn't care about their emotionals because I was already hooked on Imee's development from the start. The actors weren't bad actually. Christine Reyes as the stressed out Ate-of-the-house was impressive. Of course, she's the star here. For the other actors, I wasn't really impressed with them. I wish the story was written differently to bring out their best talent.

STORY. Bruh, I didn't enjoy the pacing. Too much tense and emotional scenes, it felt like a drag. I actually zoned out during Bongbong and Ferdinand's scene. And I saw two people on their phones during that scene too. I was expecting a good breathe of air after that but Irene's scene came next, I think. Hopefully my memory isn't bad. Also maid Biday's presence during that scene felt so out of place. I actually found it funny but it still didn't fit in appropriately. I wish the household staff had more scenes on their own since I felt they were important people in the story. If the story was written to not focus so much on the family but the Palace as a whole, I would've found it more interesting. The balance between serious and comedy needs improvement. Last thing, Robin Padilla's cameo was goddamn too cringe. What is this? The MCU? Welcome to the Malacañang-verse. And IRM 2022 during the Bongbong & Imelda scene was, er, cheesy.

THINGS I LIKED. I can't explain how the scene with Ferdinand and Imelda dancing in the middle of the Palace's chaos was nice. Ganda. Imee's scene with the staff at the end. I think that the only emotional scene I liked. The family cared for the staff and didn't simply abandon them. After Ferdinand called Imee the best maid in the Palace, the fact that the three maids were real people was a (heartwarming) twist! "Maids are not just maids."

Summary of stars deducted: 1. Terrible sound mixing and musical score was disappointing for a movie soundtrack lover 2. Lack of character exposition and development 3. Story felt like dragging and lost my interest and attention in the middle 4. Robin Padilla cringe and inappropriate comic relief (the maids deserved better!)

Everything is superb!: Since elementary, our textbooks taught us that the Marcoses were monsters and the Aquinos were the heroes. I watched the movie because I believe that it's time to hear the other side of the story, and it blew my mind. I was enlightened. Now I understand them better. I definitely recommend this movie, be prepared experience a roller coaster of emotions. Lol. The actors were exceptional, especially Christine Reyes! Hands down!!! Great casting, and amazing cinematography! Standing ovation!

Rewatched for the first time since seeing it in the cinemas in 2022. I don't support anything that happened during the Marcos regime, however, I enjoyed the movie then, even now because it was meant to show the helpers/maids who worked in the palace during the People's Revolution. Personally, I grew up always having helpers/yayas and I have tremendous respect for them, and what they do for me and my family. I’ve had helpers who have seen me grow up, took care of me as a child, and some even took part in raising me instead of doing all that for their own children. In the movie, you could see the amount of loyalty the helpers had towards the family, and that’s something that I definitely see every single day with mine. Sometimes, I just think how lucky and how blessed I am to be on the receiving end of things, because they don’t just choose to be a nanny, most times they don't really have a choice, they have to work to send their children to school, put a roof over their families heads, or to just put food on the table and make ends meet. In return, it takes significant moments away from their lives, they take care of somebody else’s kid rather than their own, they take care of somebody else’s mother or father instead of their own. Spending time that can never be given back on making someone’s life easier. Even on the hardest days, they have no choice but to keep going. When theres nothing else they can do but obey what they are being told to do. Even after all of that, they still have a smile on their face, they still do their job to the best of their ability, and for that I will always be grateful. (ly ate ann and ate jean )

Took me three years to watch this and I would be objective on this:1. Marred by uneven writing. There are times that they would inject humor when in just one scene Imee was paranoid. 2. More tell than actually showing the narrative. Each chapter has its own introduction. 3. Audio has its problems and in the first scene at the Palace, it seems that Christine has the mic alone. 4. Undefined genre, it becomes a comedy, then drama and at one point, horror. There was a point that it becomes a documentary. I guess, Darryl, pick a narrative style. 5. Production-wise, I will be nitpicking this. Instead of using the images of Cesar and Ruffa, they used FM and IM’s images instead. I need consistency because Cesar doesn’t look as much as FM. 6. Most of the time, they used the One-shot technique and engaging narrative but it was flat. 7. We don’t see much of the maids in Malacañang. I guess we have to change this to The Marcoses in Malacañang.

Maid in Malacañang sparked mixed feelings in me. The film lavish portrayal of the Marcos family's final days was captivating, but it felt like it was sugarcoating their brutal legacy. It's a reminder that history is complex, but I worry it might misrepresent the facts.

"Masama ba akong tao?"70,000 ang ipinakulong34,000 ang tinorture3,200 ang pinapatayMahigit P300 billion ang ninakaw(Amnesty International, PCGG)Inaasahan ko, at the very least, isa lang 'tong effort to humanize the Marcoses like Downfall. Kaso hindi, ano rin bang ineexpect ko sa walang hiyang direktor na 'to, pinapalabas na para bang taumbayan pa ang masama, na parang hindi inalipin ng kanilang pamilya ang Pilipinas nang mahigit dalawampu't taon (at sa ngayo'y patuloy pa rin), minaliit ang rebolusyon bilang isang pulitikal na agenda ng mga Aquino, at hindi bilang isang makamasang kilusan na nagpabagsak ng diktadurya. Nakakatakot lang talaga yung huling chapter, kasi sa bawat isang makakakita sa katarantaduhang pinapalabas nito, may limang mauuto at maniniwala sa 'totoong kasaysayang' pinaparatang ni Yap, ng mga Marcos, ng mga bumubura at bumabaluktot sa ating kasaysayan - madaling makita ang appeal nito sa masa, napakadaling ipalimot at mabago ang ating pananaw sa pamilya ng isang diktador.Ang pinakamasahol pa ay, ordinaryong mamamayan pa ang ginamit (ang mga kasambahay at PSC) para sa pagpapalaganap ng propagandang Marcos - para lamang sabihing si Imee pala yung "Maid in Malacanang" (no fucking way they did this). Hanggang ngayon, ginagamit at inaabuso pa rin ng parehong Marcos at Duterte ang taumbayan para sa sari-sariling pulitikal na layunin.Iniisip ko bago 'to panoorin na "Baka bawi naman 'to sa visuals at technical aspects" kaso hindi, ang gimmicky ng long takes, inconsistent yung audio, hindi maayos yung pagpalit from comedy (na hindi rin naman nakakatawa) to drama, ang uncomfortable ng blockings, at ang artificial ng acting ng lahat ng gumanap, high school play lang ang peg.Kahit ganito, naging matagumpay ang pelikula sa nais nitong gawin: hugasan ang pangalan at krimen ng mga Marcos, napa-upo ba naman si Bonget sa palasyo. Pero kahit anong pagbaluktot ang gawin nila sa kasaysayan, kitang kita ngayong ika-39 anibersaryo ng EDSA na tayo pa rin ang may hawak ng kasaysayan, hangga't may hindi nakakalimot, hindi ito mabubura o mapapalitan.1/2 star para sa Traydor na Pag-Ibig ni Marion Aunor, ang ganda ng kanta, pero bakit naman dito ka napunta.Putangina mo Darryl Yap, putangina ng mga Marcos, at putangina ng mga DuterteNever Again, Never Forget!

So I finally watched the entirety of this and oh my god I genuinely hate it. Sakto lang pala na I watched this around the anniversary of the declaration of Martial Law. Darryl Yap wannabe ahh tarantino.Now, throughout the entire film SOBRANG HALATA na emotional impact focus neto- specifically, the emotional impact to gain sympathy for the Marcoses. Gagi lahat ba naman ng iyakan pinepraise sina FEM and Imelda sa lahat ng mga "mabuting" nagawa daw nila. Not to mention rin how every single time the Filipino people are mentioned we are villainized just because we are fighting for the oppressed. “Hindi ko kayang labanin ang mga Pilipino”Tangina imaginin mo presidente ka tas gusto mo labanin directly mga citizens mo without even understanding why?Lumalaban daw tayo sa mga kabutihan na ginawa ng mga Marcos and malicious intent lang lahat para sirain ang pangalan nila. Eh the entire premise/the reason why we’re fighting is going over their heads. FEM saying that the revolution for the Filipino people starts when they leave the country to flee for their safety taints what it truly means to hold a revolution to fight for one’s rights.Wala, I hate this. Halatang pang brainwash with so many unnecessary emotional dialogue to get us to sympathize with them through the experiences of real life characters (the maids). The humor is so forced and out of place too. At ang pinakanakakainis is the ending scene- they really tried to be that deep huh Ang dystopian rin ng dating eh, a scene highlighting all of Imelda’s shoes and dresses tas the entire palace being so fancy. Do you really want to defend rich people who stole from the government and everyone’s damn taxes? Galing sa perang bayan lahat ng mga sapatos at damit na yan eh. Nakakaputangina, just because they gave their workers the bare minimum kailangan ba talaga sila sambahin ng ganyan? Eh andaming ninakaw ng mga Marcos atsaka pinagpapatay.Also, I really hate how badass the intro scene was like shut the fuck up darryl yap don’t u dare take inspo from good gangster filmmakers and integrate it into propaganda films. Tanginamo panot.Tldr; the Marcoses need family therapy. Never again and never forget bro.

Lies. Lies. Lies.Fact#1. There's no denying this propaganda movie was made to clear the name of the Marcoses.Fact#2. Even as a work of fiction, this movie suffers from a bad script and bad acting. The only saving grace is Cesar Montano as FEM and, in certain scenes, Ella Cruz as Irene Marcos, Karla Estrada as Santa and Beverly Salviejo as Biday.Fact#3: Delusions of grandeur and messianic complex run in the Marcos family. Hindi lang si Imelda. Pati si Imee. The Malacañang Palace is not the permanent residence of the Marcoses. In fact, your family overstayed for 21 years because of your parents' greed for power. Imee as the 'Maid in Malacañang' is DEFINITELY NOT a reliable source. I have a feeling the eldest Marcos daughter will run for President after BBM.Fact#4: Unfortunately, a lot of Filipinos will be fooled by this movie judging by the reaction of the people inside the cinemahouse. Mapapamura ka sa katangahan ng mga Pinoy.Ang hirap mong mahalin, Pilipinas.

+ Let's start with the few positives. How this film looks is amazing. Though, for most of the time, people are just standing and exchanging dialogues, the colors of this film really feels like a step-up, relative to Filipino comedies and teleseryes. Also, I guess I liked how it utilized old news footages. And, that's pretty much it.+ Anyways, leaving all politics aside (even though it's hard to do so), if we are going to just view this on the technicality of film making and writing, it's bad. The writing, sound design, and score are overly dramatic clichés you would expect from a family drama, a low-brow comedy, and from a historical and political biopic. Though I appreciate the long takes as it really let's the drama feel natural, however, it also exposes just aforementioned poor writing because it's dialogue that serves nothing to progress the story other than sending their propaganda. + But truly, one cannot really discuss how this film is written without acknowledging the context of which it arose from. If we really dissect the film, it will not stop bleeding "Marcos Apologist" and historical revisionism. It is also troubling how the film really conveniently is not interested in truly discussing the politics with enough rigor and discipline. It really overly simplifies the entire EDSA People Power to just a dangerous riot orchestrated by power hungry politicians. It leaves out all the complexity of the political climate, as well as all the money laundering which sparked the entire social crisis. Not to mention the violences inflicted during the Martial Law. There really is the sense that Daryll Yap, the director and writer, was only really interested in telling one minute moment of this dark but important part of Philippine history. And he did not even discipline himself enough to not fall prey to self-indulgence. He really wrote it as if its a novel which ironically, made all of the actors in this film feel like they are overacting. + What is also troubling is how it did not even shy away from truly depicting the regal and glamorous life of the Marcos' in Malacañang. From the number of loyal maids, every wall plastered with life size portraits, easy international travels, among others. And with that kind of glamorous mise en scene, the audacity of this film to mention that the Marcos are not elitists, and that it's the reason for the hate they get. + Christine Reyes, portraying a younger Sen. Imee Marcos, who happens to be a creative and executive producer of this film, had the highest screen time with acting that knows only to scream frantically. It really is interesting that the senator allowed herself to be depicted and written like this, a controlling paranoid daughter flustered by their family's downfall. And how they revealed she is the Maid in Malacañang? Wow. + And let me just point out how blasphemous this film can get sometimes. Other than the regal mise en scene that competes with churches and their number of Christian iconographies. The scene where President Marcos scolds his son, Bongbong Marcos, the camera gradually and steadily circles around the two as they exchange their dramatic dialogue. The scene is honestly one that I can appreciate because of how it chose to keep this camera circling them technique continue on one long take. But during this long take, there are a handful of moments when the ceiling lights goes behind the President's head resembles a saint with a halo. It's a small nitpick but, dear Jesus, this film really wants to be on the Marcos' good side. + Another nitpick I want to highlight is how in the scene where Bongbong and Imelda Marcos are talking, they seem to have overestimated the Philippine government after the Dictatorship, stating once they leave, the people of the Philippines would do everything not to let them come back. It does make the audience wonder, and potentially realize the failures of the republic that came after. But what bothers me is this will only paint the democratic and liberal ideas, that should govern us, with yellow And because of it, the discourse of political awareness goes down as just another color contest. And that "IRM 2022" just screams corny.+ There's no substance to this film other than the blatant propagandist nature of it. I recommend watching, not to support this types of film, but to persecute it.

Nakakahiya lang…Looking for a movie to assist with Tagalog exposure, I thought this one might stand out amid what looked mostly like a sea of lukewarm romantic comedies. As it happens, this was substantially worse than I could possibly have feared about the others. You know you’re in trouble right from the jump when Imee Marcos is listed as both a creative and executive producer and then turns out to be the main character of the film. I suppose you can’t blame the Marcos clan for trying to further whitewash history now that they’ve fully completed their comeback with the ascension of Bongbong to the presidency a month before this was released, but I almost wonder why they even bothered when the attempt was so dire. This movie is two hours long and it could have cut down to about 20 minutes total - most of the runtime is occupied by interminable scenes of characters saying anything and everything they’re thinking, none of which would be particularly interesting even if most of it weren’t focused on the thesis that Ferdinand Marcos was not an oppressive dictator but rather a Great Man who Loved His People, Actually. Even by Filipino movie standards the overacting is intense - virtually every member of the main cast gets at least one showpiece to absolutely devour the scenery. The actress playing Imee screams so much she must have needed a lozenge by the end of filming (how this was intended as a flattering portrait of a producer of the film I have no idea, but I guess she is referred to as a “genius” multiple times).This reminded me of nothing so much as the kind of thing that might be dumped out by American *cough* “auteur” Dinesh D’Souza. It evinces absolutely zero talent on the part of anyone involved - the acting stinks, the writing would stink even if the message weren’t horrendous, the tone lurches wildly between melodrama and slapstick for no apparent reason, and the long takes (with their constantly moving camera) are insanely tedious. Paul Thomas Anderson this ain’t. But you actually have to appreciate how badly this is made - if this were a better movie, it might actually have some hope of convincing people of what it’s trying to do. But it’s such a mess it’s hard to imagine anyone getting all the way through unless they’re already enormous Marcos fans or absolute gluttons for punishment like me. For anyone else, don’t waste your time, and I do mean waste. There are easier ways to learn Tagalog than trying to sit through this joke.

Ang cinema ay audio-visual medium. Pwedeng panoorin tong MiM nang nakapikit dahil lahat ng information ay nasa dialogue na. Mas gumawa ang produksyon ni Daryll Yap ng radio drama kaysa pelikula. Yung pabibong one-shot unang tatlong chapter e hindi rin naman nakakamangha dahil wala namang action. Astig ang one-shot sa mga zombie movie o war movie dahil sa continuous orchestrated action. Pero kung puro lang naman dada ang gagawin e balewala din. Mas awtobiograpikal ito kaysa politikal. Memoir to ni Imee Marcos (the best maid in malacanang - FM). Siya ang producer e. Yung mga tunay na kasambahay sa malacanang noon ay halos narrator lang dito. Ni wala nga sila sa poster. Si Marcos Sr., sa persona niya during his times, e eloquent at strong man. Dito sa pelikula, binaliktad. Siya lang yung hindi matatas magsalita kung tutuusin. Paulit-ulit na nakakairita na naghahabol ng mga salita. Lalo na doon sa eksenang pinagagalitan niya si Bongbong. Tina-try gawing tao si Marcos Sr. PInakikita kuno yung malambot na side nila, yung hindi inihaharap sa publiko. Ganoon din si Imelda, at si Bongbong na may oedipus complex pa ata. At yung Irene ba yun. Mukhang tatakbo si Imee Marcos sa susunod na eleksyon dahil strongwoman siya ng pelikula, pinapabango ang sarili. Bilang propaganda palyado din ito. Dahil magagalit, matatawa, o aantukin lang nang husto ang mga "oposisyon". NI-re-reinforce lang nito ang parasocial relationship sa pamilya marcos ng mga loyalista. Di bale na ang mga alanganin pa ang politika dahil madaling i-rebut ang mga ipinarinig sa pelikula. Ganito pala jakulin ng mga mayayaman ang sarili nila.

Those who are too trusting, their enemies may take something from them. It is a lesson of trust, loyalty and truth. The film’s cinematography and soundtrack is outstanding for an independent film. There is so much to dislike about Maid in Malacañang that there is not even one redeeming value in this blatant propaganda movie.The cast performance, which I thought would be the best (and only) part of the movie, ended up being disastrous. Not only they are terribly miscast, but they also don't sound like the Marcos family at all. Even if Christine Reyes had the "best" acting in this movie, it does not say much when she doesn't even look like Imee Marcos and the dialogue is terribly written. All of the budget to make them look accurate to the Marcoses went to Ruffa Guitterez's wig as Imelda and the filmmakers are lazily relying on the viewers to identify which one is who in the Marcos family. The cinematography is also not good. The use of pseudo "one-take" shot framing using the square aspect ratio to highlight the film's time period just makes this film so ugly and ingenuine. It's like I am watching a poorly-edited Lana Del Rey music video.The Vincentiments humor in some of the scenes is just terrible and very out-of-place for a period film like this. This is what you get for a film written by someone whose previous background in filmmaking was tacky sex comedies.Perhaps the most offensive part of this film is that it attempts to put the entire family in a positive light as if they are not held responsible for the things that took place during Martial Law. To justify their lapses, the film instead presents the Marcoses as genuinely good people who happen to be naive and absent-minded about the people who betrayed them and Imee (who is the film's main POV and the real-life senator is also a producer of the movie) happens to be the only smart one in the family. I just cannot fantom how people fall for this obvious lie, yet their supporters will take them as facts on the surface.It's so annoying how films like Maid in Malacañang, as well as its counter-programming film Katips, only aim to fuel our culture war here in the Philippines. Both of these films are only made to strengthen the confirmation bias of their target audience, forcing them to accept whatever they presented as facts instead of asking the audience to ponder the message they want to tell.Among all of the bad-to-mediocre Martial Law and post-ML era films made since President Bongbong Marcos became president, this is the worst one of the bunch. Never again.

A gross spectacle in hindsight, one that embraces and glorifies every single form of manipulative and almost fascistic appeal from the characters. It's rather devoid of any sort of emotion and dipped into an endless pit of constant egotism by Darryl Yap that it's embarrassing to look at. When we are introduced to Marcos family, the first thing they with the large and spacious hallways of their palace, filled to the brim with gold, maids, and a polish mansion with never a single flaw in hindsight. When we are then introduced to the protesters, it's through low-angle shots, a filter of uneducated and poor peasants that almost sees them as derogatory of any kind. A film both ville and technically incompetent in direction. You can compare this to films such as Birth of a Nation or Triumph of Will, but at least those two films have clear reason and direction on why they exist a propaganda. In Maid In Manacalang, everything is so convoluted that it almost feels like a parody on Facebook rather than something to take seriously with. This film isn't even about any maids, and they probably just served as a light cover-up with the marketing. I hope Luis Bunuel comes back from the dead to make Darryl Yap live the events of "Un Chien Adalou"

Historically distorted films have marred history for decades now. Certain movies like Argo, Braveheart, Pocahontas, and Patton had their fair share of twisting history in exchange for spectacle. Even movie juggernauts like Lawrence of Arabia or Titanic have been lambasted because they portray actual events. The difference between those films and this is that they have been created with cinematic accuracies that provide enjoyment to the audience.In the eyes of the filmmakers, what matters most is if the movie generates income, even if it's executed poorly story-wise and technicality-wise.Maid in Malacañang, despite its well-divided 10-chapter plot, is a mixture of unnecessary inconsistencies shown in a very cheap spectacle style. Inconsistent shots that tried to execute long takes, like in 1917 or Birdman, but the character blockings and setup make it more annoying than pleasing. Cheap sets used to represent the Malacañan Palace (The grandest mansion in the Philippines) looked like a huge village home full of creaks and poor paints. Mixing in 21st Century Gen-z dialogues to add humor that doesn't work well. And line delivery seemed like the actors tried to portray their roles because they were asked to and did not practice well.But I got to say, it takes a lot of heart and brains to really watch this one.Because to me, who has watched a good chunk of films, especially award-winning ones, made this film more annoying than enjoyable even if you don't bother comparing it to actual history. I know we are not always gunning for our movies to be "world-class" because filmmaking is still a business, and sales are more important because it generates money. Maid in Malacañang is definitely a tad below the low-class filmmaking because the whole movie felt like it was done in a rush, like a school project. Yet, it was still watched by a lot of people.I am wondering, have our standards on how we watch films gotten really low?

Fresh from the success of winning the Philippines' 2022 Presidential elections through their endless propaganda and trolling, Darryl Yap brings us his latest pessimus opus: the fictionalized retelling of the end of Marcos family's dictatorship, focusing on their last three days in Malacañang Palace before their exile in Hawaii following the People Power Revolution in 1986.In the film, Cristine Reyes play the fictionalized version of Imee Marcos, who returns to the Philippines after she is summoned by his father, a fictional, mild-mannered version of Ferdinand Marcos (played by Cesar Montano). Upon returning to the film's cheap-looking version of Malacanang, the fictional version of Imee Marcos learns about a failed assassination plot against their family. All throughout the film's excessively long running time, the fictional version of the Marcos family face betrayal of several high-ranking officials, including several Palace staff, food shortages, plus fear and anxiety from the growing number of the "mindless" crowds joining the EDSA revolution. After ten excruciating chapters and 105 wasted minutes, the family, upon the persuasion of the fictional version of Imee, decides to leave the Palace, with the help of m0therfvcking senator Robin Padilla as Gen. Fabian Ver, the Chief of Staff of the AFP under the Marcos Administration. The film ends with people storming the Palace, looting and destroying its premises.Penned and directed by Yap, with the real Imee Marcos serving as the film's creative producer, this propaganda film is actually not the worst Filipino film of 2022 for me (that recognition still belongs to the Claudine Barretto revenge drama "Deception"). But this is definitely the most boring local film from last year. The film opens with a text saying the following: " Ang pelikulang ito ay naglalaman ng mga tunay na kaganapan, sa gitna ng kasaysayan, sa gilid ng kaguluhan, sa likod ng media, na ngayo'y ihaharap sa Bayan." Early on, it already conditions the viewers' minds that what they're about to see is based on a true story. It even used real life footage and clips from the time of the EDSA revolution to make it feel more "real." There's even a voice-over, claiming that Cory Aquino herself was advocating for the public's civil disobedience. We all know how it's going to end, with Marcoses as mere victims of fate and tragedy. Nothing is surprisng anymore. In short, their version of the truth, so it's predictable from the get-go. Kuwento niyo yan, eh.On top of this, the forced comedy makes it even more painful to watch. Can you imagine, the actual "maids" in the movie are the ones that make it more cringy, acting like some chorus and providing comic relief (which all failed). Karla Estrada and Beverly Sarmiento in particular, are both excruciating to watch and listen to. It feels more like a series of Vincentiments skit with bigger names, stitched together to form a film. It also looks like one. It's cheap. It's boring. It's always loud (lots of shouting, as usual). It's very dependent on stirring controversy. Very Darryl Yap.Right from its early scenes, the film's main focus is on the fictionalized version Imee Marcos, making it feel like she's the hero of the story. It's actually pretty confusing, because I remember the real Imee Marcos saying before that she was "too young" when she heard about Martial Law, but here, she's portrayed as a full-grown, fierce and intelligent woman, which we all know are all made up, just like her claim that she is "one of the first female graduates from an Ivy League School -- Princeton University, graduating with honors."And as expected, it paints Ferdinand Marcos as a naive and innocent victim who trusted the wrong people, and the entire family as sad victims. Boohoo. "Palagi lang mabait! Yan, yan yung ginamit nila para mapagbagsak ka. Sobrang tiwala mo sa kanila," said the fictional version of Imee. They did get one detail right though: that young Bong-bong is a party animal, as proven by their massive private video collection obtained by the media, including the infamous "We Are The World" video during his birthday celebration on board the presidential yacht Ang Pangulo.To make matters worse, all the scenes lack tension. They all feel dull, despite how loud the characters shout their lines. The only thing that adds emotions to its scenes is its manipulative and overbearing music. The cinematography employs long shots which, instead of giving the film an authentic feel, makes it look more boring. The performances only add up to the film's blandness, like Ruffa Gutierrez's performance, who looks like she doesn't know any other facial expressions. She's like Jennifer Coolidge, but in a very bad way. You don't know whether she's about to laugh, about to cry, or she's just constipated. The only good decision that this film had is having Cristine Reyes playing the improved, cinematic version of Imee.It's packed with lies after lies, that it is so hard to keep track."Galit na galit sila dahil hindi tayo nanggaling sa elitistang angkan. Galit na galit sila dahil probinsyano lang tayo. Galit na galit sila dahil mahal tayo ng mga tao. Pero hindi ko magawang magalit sa kanila," says the sadboi ex-President in the movie. And I'm not even going to dig further in that scene featuring Giselle Sanchez's portrayal of Cory Aquino playing mahjong with nuns, which has been debunked by the Carmelite sisters themselves.Long, loud, lame and lifeless, this fictionalized, propagandist film from Viva Films and Darryl Yap is nothing more than a disgusting attempt to whitewash the crimes and atrocities under the Marcos dictatorship, and to suck-up to the current administration.The design is very Darryl Yap.
